questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of recurrent nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and declining scholastic performance. An X-ray is done which is shown below. Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing enlarged adenoids are suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinolalia aperta(Hypernasality) would not be seen in this condition, but rhinolalia clausa(Hyponasality) would be seen instead.

Adenoids also known as nasopharyngeal tonsils are prone to physiological enlargement during childhood. Affected children typically present with symptoms of nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, sinusitis, and rhinolalia clausa (loss of nasal tone of voice). They may also experience aprosexia (inability to concentrate) leading to declining scholastic performance. These children have characteristic adenoid facies marked by a dull expression, open mouth, pinched in nose, high arched palate, and crowded upper teeth. 

When symptoms are bothersome, it is removed by adenoidectomy. Otherwise, decongestant nasal drops and antihistamines can be used.

Indications for adenoidectomy:

  • Symptoms like snoring, mouth breathing, and rhinolalia clausa due to adenoid hypertrophy
  • Recurrent ear discharge
  • Dental malocclusion
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion secondary to adenoid hyperplasia

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft/ submucous palate: Adenoidectomy leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency in these cases and may cause rhinolalia aperta.
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Active local infection

questions.text: A person did not consume food for almost 20 hours during a protest. Which of the following enzymes catalyzes an irreversible step in the pathway maintaining blood glucose levels at this stage?
questions.solution:
In a person starving for more than 18 hours, the source of energy is gluconeogenesis. One of the irreversible steps in gluconeogenesis is catalyzed by fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase.

Gluconeogenesis is the source of glucose in the second stage of fasting (after 18 hours) and has 4 irreversible steps catalyzed by:

  1. Pyruvate carboxylase
  2. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase
  3. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase
  4. Glucose-6-phosphatase

Enolase catalyzes the reversible conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to 2-phosphoglycerate during gluconeogenesis (Option C). The below image shows the steps of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

The first stage of fasting begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting, which is 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. Glycogen phosphorylase (Option B) is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis.

In the second stage of fasting gluconeogenesis is the source of glucose. It begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days. Substrates for gluconeogenesis are glucogenic amino acids ( mainly alanine) from the muscle and glycerol from adipose tissue. These glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

In the third stage of fasting (after 2 days), lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase (Option D). It is stimulated by increased glucagon: insulin ratio. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA. Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose.

In the final stage after several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with itching and a rash located on his torso. He also complains of chronic cough with sputum production and mucoid diarrhea. His laboratory investigations reveal peripheral eosinophilia and raised serum IgE levels. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Cough with sputum production, mucoid diarrhea, eosinophilia and larva currens is likely caused by Strongyloides stercolaris. 

In the image, the patient has multiple erythematous tracts in the skin. This is called larva currens or racing larvae caused by migrating larvae within the skin and is seen in Strongyloides infection. Strongyloides stercolaris is a nematode that infects the small intestine. It is the smallest nematode that causes infection in humans. In addition to the parasitic cycle, it also has a free-living soil cycle by feeding on bacteria. Humans get infected when the third-stage filariform larvae penetrate their bare skin. 

Clinical manifestations can be grouped as follows: 

  1. Cutaneous manifestations: 
    1. Dermatitis characterized by pruritus and erythema: This occurs at the site where the larvae penetrate the skin. 
    2. Larva currens or 'racing' larvae:  Characterized by multiple urticarial tracts in the skin caused by migrating larvae
  2. Pulmonary manifestations: Bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthma. 
  3. Intestinal manifestations: Mucoid diarrhea, protein losing enteropathy and paralytic ilieus. 
  4. Hyperinfection occurs in immunocompromised individuals due to extensive autoinfection and worm load. 

Diagnosis of strongyloides is by the wet mount of stool or aspirates of sputum, jejunum or duodenum, showing rhabditiform larvae. Peripheral eosinophilia is present and IgE may be raised. The image below shows the rhabditiform larvae.

Treatment involves ivermectin (200ug/kg/day for 2 days) or albendazole (400mg/day for 3 days). 

Other options: 

Option A - Aspergillus fumigatus is an opportunistic infection that causes allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), aspergilloma, and invasive aspergillosis. ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to the aspergillus antigen causing asthma and alveolitis. Aspergilloma is the formation of a fungus ball within a preexisting lung cavity leading to hemoptysis. Invasive aspergillosis begins as pneumonia and becomes disseminated in immunocompromised individuals. 

Option C - Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis. The adult worms block the lymphatic vessels leading to inflammation and granuloma formation. This causes hard pitting or brawny edema. It can present as lymphadenitis, lymphedema, hydrocele, and elephantiasis. 

Option D - Enterobius vermicularis is also known as 'pin worm'. It causes intense pruritus of the anal region in children. The worm has a tendency to migrate out of the anus at night leading to disturbed sleep and nocturnal enuresis. In females, it can cause irritation of the vagina and vulva and chronic salpingitis. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of the synthesis of thyroid hormones in order.
  1. Oxidation
  2. Coupling reaction
  3. Transport via sodium-iodide symporter
  4. Organification/Iodination
  5. Transport via pendrin
questions.solution:
The formation of thyroid hormones starts with the trapping of iodine via sodium-iodide symporter and its transport into the follicle via pendrin. This is followed by oxidation, organification, and coupling reaction.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (Option 3) actively takes up I- (iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. The process of concentrating iodide in the cell is known as iodide trapping. Iodide is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter (Option 5).
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by the thyrocytes and secreted into colloids.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation (Option 1): TPO oxidizes iodine in the presence of H2O2 
    • Organification (Option 4): TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions (Option 2): TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes in the colloid from the thyroid cells. This releases thyroxine and triiodothyronine into the peripheral blood. 
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone.

questions.text:
Match the following spinal deformity with their mechanism
  1. Knuckle
  2. Gibbus
  3. Kyphosis

A. Collapse of anterior vertebral bodies

B. Collapse of a single vertebra


C. Collapse of 2-3 vertebral levels
questions.solution:
The correct match is

Deformity Mechanism
Knuckle Collapse of a single vertebra
Gibbus/Kyphus Collapse of 2-3 vertebral levels
Kyphosis Collapse of anterior vertebral bodies

 

Spinal tuberculosis may present with the following skeletal deformities:

Deformity Mechanism Description
Knuckle Collapse of a single vertebra Prominence of a single spinous process
Gibbus/Kyphus Collapse of 2-3 vertebral levels Sharp posterior angulation
Kyphosis Collapse of anterior vertebral bodies Exaggerated curvature of the vertebral column
Concertina collapse / vertebra plana Collapse of the entire vertebral body Seen in tuberculosis of the central vertebral body

 

Tb spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbus.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process) is affected.

Clinical features of spinal tuberculosis:

  • Back pain, stiffness and reduced movements are the usual early complaints
  • Cautious gait - a person with spinal TB will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement
  • Pott's paraplegia
  • Cold abscess
  • Concertina collapse - a type of compression fracture without involvement of the interverterbral disc
  • Deformity - kyphus and gibbus (gradually increasing prominence).

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presented with reduced urine output, swelling of his feet, and eyelid puffiness for 1 week. He also complains of back pain for the past 3 months, unresponsive to painkillers. The investigations done are given below. Which of the following is the likely cause of renal failure in this patient?
  • Hemoglobin - 7.1 g/dl
  • Serum urea - 63 mg/dl
  • Serum creatinine - 3.9 mg/dl
  • Urine analysis - positive for Bence-Jones proteins
  • ESR - 75 mm/h
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with backache for the past 3 months, renal failure (elevated urea and creatinine, with peripheral edema), along with Bence-Jones proteinuria and elevated ESR is suggestive of multiple myeloma. The most likely cause of renal failure in this patient is hypercalcemia.

The other factor which contributes to renal failure is the excretion of the light chains. An increase in the amount of light chains presented to the renal tubules leads to tubular damage, either directly due to the light chains, or due to the release of lysosomal enzymes. 

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increased osteoclast activity and accelerated bone destruction. Furthermore, there is suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include: 

  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic and normochromic anemia
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes
  • Elevated ESR
  • Normal alkaline phosphatase due to suppression of osteoblast activity.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein
  • Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins)

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma include: 

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically: (CRAB features)
    • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >2 g/dL below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET).
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%
    • Serum involved / uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater.
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: A patient underwent a trabeculectomy, following which he developed a headache. Examination revealed that the anterior chamber was flat, the Seidel test result was negative, and the intraocular pressure was raised. Which of the following can worsen this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on clinical features is malignant glaucoma. Pilocarpine can worsen this patient's condition and is contraindicated in malignant glaucoma. 

Malignant glaucoma is seen after intraocular surgery such as trabeculectomy. The forward flow of aqueous is blocked as the tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens/IOL/anterior hyaloid of the vitreous. Hence, aqueous humor collects in the vitreous cavity.

Clinical features:

  • Persistent shallow or flat anterior chamber
  • Negative Seidel’s test result
  • Raised intra-ocular pressure

Treatment

  • Atropine:
    • Malignant glaucoma is also called inverse glaucoma since atropine is used.
    • It dilates the ciliary ring and increases the distance between the ciliary processes and the equator of the lens, thereby tightening the zonule and pulling the lens posteriorly into its normal position.
  • Intravenous mannitol may be used if mydriatics are ineffective, in order to shrink the vitreous gel and allow the lens to move posteriorly.
  • Nd:YAG laser hyaloidotomy - making an opening in the anterior hyaloid membrane
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

Miotics are contraindicated as they can cause the ciliary zonules to slack, the lens to move forward and further shallowing of the anterior chamber. So mydriatic and cycloplegic agents such as atropine are administered.

Match the following mood disorders with the minimum duration required for diagnosis according to DSM 5.
Mood disorder Duration
I. Major depressive episode A. 2 years
II. Dysthymia B. 4 days
III. Manic episode C. 2 weeks
IV. Hypomanic episode D. 1 week

choices.text: I - C, II - A, III - D, IV - B
I - A, II - B, III - D, IV - C
I - B, II - C, III - A, IV - D
I - D, II - A, III - C, IV - B

questions.solution:
The correct answer is I - C, II - A, III - D, IV - B.

The following are the minimum duration required for diagnosis according to Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders - 5 (DSM-5):

Mood disorder Duration
Major depressive episode 2 weeks
Dysthymia 2 years 
Manic episode 1 week
Hypomanic episode 4 days 

 

Major depressive disorder- It must be accompanied by at least 4 of the following symptoms:

  • Change in appetite
  • Change in weight
  • Change in sleep and activity
  • Lack of energy
  • Feelings of guilt
  • Problems with thinking and making decisions
  • Recurring thoughts of death or suicide 

Dysthymia- It is characterized by symptoms of depression lasting two years. The symptoms are not severe enough to fit the diagnosis of a major depressive episode.   

Manic episode- It is characterized by a distinctive period of persistently and abnormally elevated or irritable mood lasting for at least one week. The diagnosis can also be made if it lasts for less than one week but is serious enough to require hospitalization.   

Hypomanic episode- It is similar to mania but it does not result in impairment of social or occupational function. The episode should last at least 4 days for a diagnosis of hypomania.

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

Cyclothymic disorder

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing technique shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The suturing technique shown in the image is mattress suture.

Mattress sutures can be vertical or horizontal and are used to create either an eversion or inversion of the wound edges. The initial suture is inserted in the same way as an interrupted suture, but then, the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again, as seen in the figure. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it produces an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially in settings where the edges are not easily approximated.

In interrupted sutures, the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and should exit at a right angle with the skin. The needle should be rotated through the tissue and should not be dragged through to avoid unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. If 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the distance from the entry point of the suture to the edge of the wound must be 'x'. Distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. 

Continuous suture technique: The first suture is inserted in a manner identical to that in an interrupted suture. The remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached. Care should be taken to maintain the tension of the suture to avoid excessive tension or leaving it too slack; hence, the use of an assistant is warranted. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

Subcuticular sutures is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. In this technique, small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound, and then, they are gently pulled together. This causes an approximation of the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

questions.text: An elderly man with a history of hypertension for the past 15 years, presents to the clinic with a history of palpitations for the past 4 hours. The doctor performed an ECG and it showed the presence of an irregularly irregular ventricular rate with the absence of P waves. Which among the following waves will be absent in the jugular venous pressure tracing of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes atrial fibrillation. Wave marked as 1 in jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing is 'a' wave and this will be absent in this patient.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) characterized by a loss of organized atrial mechanical contraction is commonly seen in elderly people with an underlying cardiac disease. Other risk factors are hypertension, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and sleep apnea. It is diagnosed by ECG which will show the absence of distinct P-waves and an irregular ventricular response. The a wave of the JVP reflecting atrial contraction is absent in this case as there is no organized atrial contraction occurring.

Jugular venous pressure is used to assess central venous pressure. The internal jugular vein is preferred for the measurement because it does not have valves and is directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. Venous pressure is measured as the vertical distance between the top of the jugular venous pulsation and the angle of Louis. A distance >4.5 cm at a 30° elevation is considered abnormal.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman came with complaints of dull-aching pain in her hips and back. She was diagnosed with bilateral mixed conductive and a sensorineural hearing loss last month. A blood workup revealed normal calcium and phosphate levels. X-ray of her lower limbs showed flame-shaped osteolytic lesion and cortical thickening. Which of the following is the best among the given treatment options?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Paget's disease of the bone. It is also known as osteitis deformans. The most appropriate treatment for this patient with Paget's disease is IV Zoledronate- a bisphosphonate. 

It is characterized by an increased bone turnover due to a disorganized, alternating, and increased rate of osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. It may be monostotic or polyostotic. 

Clinically, it is seen more commonly in people over the age of 50. A majority of the patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients present with bone pain, which is constant and dull aching and mostly involves the long bones of the lower limbs, back, and hips. They may have deformities such as bowing of bones, the tibia bending anteriorly and the femur bending anterolaterally. Skull bones may be enlarged and the base of the skull may be flattened. Disorganized and increased bone deposition may lead to stenosis of various canals and foramina resulting in compression of cranial nerves, spinal cord, and nerve roots (due to spinal stenosis). Hearing loss is a fairly common feature, due to compression of the cranial nerve and otosclerosis resulting in mixed sensorineural and conductive hearing loss. Pathological fractures of the long bones may be seen. One of the most baleful complications, however, is the increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. 

Other complications include osteoarthritis, high-output cardiac failure, and hypercalcemia. 

Laboratory investigations reveal-

  • Normal calcium and phosphate levels
  • Increased bone-specific alkaline phosphatase due to increased osteoblastic activity
  • Increased serum levels of collagen crosslinked peptides such as CTX (C-telopeptide) due to bone resorption
  • Increased urinary markers such as hydroxyproline, deoxypyridinoline, C-telopeptide, and N-telopeptide.

X-ray findings in Paget's disease reveal both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions. Characteristic radiographic findings include-

  • Brim sign- Seen in Paget's disease of the pelvis due to a thickened iliopectineal line.
  • Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 
  • Picture-frame appearance may be seen in vertebral bodies due to enlarged coarse trabeculae surrounded by a prominent radiodense periphery.
  • Ivory vertebra sign may be seen due to diffuse and homogeneous increase in opacity of a vertebral body.
  • Osteogenesis circumscripta describes circumscribed patches of radiolucency due to osteoporosis in the skull.

The aim of the treatment of Paget disease is to limit excessive bone remodeling and to reduce pain. The mainstay of treatment is therefore bisphosphonates as they inhibit osteoclastic activity, limiting bone resorption and disease progression. IV zoledronate is the preferred bisphosphonate. It is administered as a single IV dose of 4-5 mg and has the most sustained response. It is, however, contraindicated in renal insufficiency. 

Therapeutic uses of bisphosphonates- 

  • Osteoporosis including postmenopausal and steroid-induced
  • Paget disease 
  • Tumor-associated osteolysis 
  • Hypercalcemia.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of staring spells in school. She is diagnosed with absence seizures. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for ethosuximide, a drug commonly used for this condition?

GABA: gamma-Aminobutyric acid

choices.text: Inhibition of the T-type calcium channels

questions.solution:
Ethosuximide is commonly used in children suffering from absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is the inhibition of T-type calcium channels.

Absence seizures originate in the thalamus and produce the pathognomonic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG. This pattern is produced due to the intrinsic properties of the low threshold T-type calcium channels of the thalamus. These channels are activated at a much lower threshold and produce larger currents as compared to most other calcium channels in the brain. Hence, inhibition of these T-type calcium currents in the neurons of the thalamus by ethosuximide is effective for the management of absence seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Valproate acts by blocking both calcium and sodium channels. It is effective in the treatment of absence, myoclonic, focal, and tonic-clonic seizures.

Option B: Vigabatrin inhibits GABA transaminase and thus increases GABA concentration in the brain. It is the drug of choice for infantile spasms seen in tuberous sclerosis.

Option C: Benzodiazepines enhance GABA-mediated synaptic inhibition. Benzodiazepines act at GABAA receptors and increase the frequency, but not duration, of openings at GABA-activated Cl− channels

questions.text: Which of the following is a monoclonal antibody that increases the risk of developing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in anti-JCV antibody-positive patients?
questions.solution:
Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that increases the risk of the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in JC antibody-positive patients.

Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin. Natalizumab is indicated for the treatment of adult patients with relapsing-remitting MS as well as active, secondary progressive disease. Natalizumab is also indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe Crohn’s disease that does not adequately respond to conventional therapies or TNFα inhibitors.

There is a significant increase in the risk of development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) after natalizumab administration. PML is a rare, opportunistic viral infection of the brain caused by the human polyomavirus 2, also known as John Cunningham virus (JCV). PML can lead to death or severe disability. A series of factors are known to increase the risk of PML in patients treated with natalizumab. These include the presence of anti-JCV antibodies, prolonged treatment with natalizumab, or prior treatment with immunosuppressants such as mitoxantrone, azathioprine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, or MMF.

Other options:

Option A: Fingolimod is a sphingosine-1-phosphate inhibitor. Cardiac complications are common if used in individuals over the age of 50 and those with a history of cardiac disease. VZV antibody testing must be conducted to mitigate the risk of disseminated herpes zoster.

Option B: Teriflunomide inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme, dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase present in de novo pyrimidine synthesis. It is a teratogenic drug.

Option C: Ocrelizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the CD20 molecule. Adverse effects include a low risk of development of PML and a slight increase in the risk of development of infections.

questions.text: Which of the following Leopold’s maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus ?
questions.solution:
Leopold’s 1 i.e. fundal grip is used to assess fetal lie.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of the fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers.

Leopold’s maneuvers are done by four obstetric grips:

  1. Leopold’s 1 (Fundal grip): It assesses the uterine fundus. It helps the identification of fetal lie and fetal presentation. The breech gives the sensation of a large, nodular mass, whereas the head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
  2. Leopold’s 2 (Lateral grip): It assesses the presenting part's position. The second maneuver is accomplished as the palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted. On one side, a hard, resistant structure is felt-the back. On the other, numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt-the fetal extremities
  3. Leopold’s 3 (Pawlik's grip): It helps in the confirmation of fetal presentation. The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass, usually the head, will be felt.
  4. Leopold’s 4 (Pelvic grip): It assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a history of sexual assault followed by amenorrhea. Her urine pregnancy test was positive. Which of the following is the most likely maturation index of her vaginal epithelium?
questions.solution:
The most likely maturation index of vaginal epithelium in a pregnant woman is 0/95/5.

The maturation index is also known as the karyopyknotic index. It is the ratio of mature squamous (superficial) cells to the intermediate and parabasal cells, expressed in percentage. It is expressed in three numbers expressing each of these cell types in percentages, in the format of parabasal cells/intermediate cells/superficial cells. Parabasal cells are round small and basophilic. Intermediate cells are transparent and basophilic. Superficial cells are thin, large, and acidophilic.

Estrogen produces superficial cell maturation; progesterone, androgen, corticosteroids, and pregnancy produce intermediate cell maturation, whereas lack of any hormonal activity produces parabasal cell dominance.

In pregnancy, the most likely maturation index is 0/95/5. During pregnancy, if the ratio of superficial cells is more than 10 percent it denotes the progesterone deficiency.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old female patient presents with a cough, low-grade fever, and hemoptysis. Investigations reveal a cavitary lesion on her right lung apex, which on biopsy reveals caseous necrosis. She also tests positive for PPD intradermal skin test. Which of the following diseases have a similar pathophysiology of hypersensitivity?
  1. Multiple sclerosis
  2. Goodpasture syndrome
  3. Serum sickness
  4. Contact dermatitis
  5. Inflammatory bowel disease
questions.solution:
The pathophysiology in this case of pulmonary tuberculosis is type 4 hypersensitivity and can be seen in cases of multiple sclerosis, contact dermatitis, and inflammatory bowel disease.

The clinical scenario with complaints of cough, low-grade fever, and hemoptysis is suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis. The diagnosis is further supported by a cavitary lesion in the apex of the lung, a biopsy showing caseous necrosis and the PPD intradermal skin test(tuberculin skin test). The pathophysiology is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction that is mediated by activated macrophages. In T-cell mediated (Type 4) hypersensitivity, granulomatous inflammation, and tissue damage are by Th-1-mediated macrophage activation and the killing of bacteria. Interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) released by Th-1 cells is the critical mediator that activates the macrophages. This activation differentiates the macrophages into epithelioid cells that aggregate to form granuloma.

This reaction can be produced experimentally by intracutaneous injection of antigen in a previously immunized animal that has circulating antibodies against the antigen. As the antigen diffuses into the vessel wall, it binds with the preformed antibody, and immune complexes are formed locally. These complexes precipitate in the vessel walls and cause fibrinoid necrosis.

Other options: 

  • Goodpasture syndrome is caused by type 2 hypersensitivity and is antibody-mediated.
  • Serum sickness is caused by type 3 hypersensitivity or immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. The deposition of antigen-antibody complexes leads to complement activation.

questions.text: A neuroscientist was studying the function of various regions in the brain. He made a lesion over a particular area on both sides of the brain. As a result, the experimental animal becomes passive and stops eating and drinking. The lesion in which of the following areas is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Lesions of the bilateral ‘lateral’ hypothalamus result in a state of passivity. The animal will stop eating and drinking and will starve itself to death. The lateral hypothalamus is involved in controlling the desire to eat, drink and increases the general activity level of the animal.

Other options:

Option A: Ventromedial hypothalamus is involved in bringing satiety and calmness.

Option B: Posterior hypothalamus has the primary motor center for shivering and is involved in increasing the body temperature.

Option D: Piriform cortex in males is involved in increasing the sexual drive. It is otherwise involved in odor perception.

questions.text: A microbiologist performed Elek's gel precipitation test to determine the toxigenicity of a bacterium. Which of the following results show that the strain of the bacterium is toxigenic?

choices.text: Absence of a zone of hemolysis between antiserum and antigen
Presence of a zone of hemolysis between antiserum and antigen
Absence of a line of precipitation between antiserum and antigen
Presence of a line of precipitation between antiserum and antigen

questions.solution:
The presence of a line of precipitation between antitoxin and antigen in Elek's gel precipitation test shows that the strain of bacterium is toxigenic.

Elek test is an in vitro immunoprecipitation (immunodiffusion) test used to determine whether or not a strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is toxigenic. 

A rectangular piece of filter paper containing diphtheria antitoxin is placed on a petri dish filled with 20% normal horse serum agar. The agar solidifies, and the surface is dried. Streaks of bacterial strains are made on the agar, intersecting with the filter paper strip. Positive and negative controls are included for comparison. The dish is then incubated at 37°C for 24-48 hours. If the bacterial strains produce toxins, the toxins will diffuse in the agar and react with the antitoxin on the filter paper, resulting in a visible line of precipitation. This line indicates that the strain is capable of producing toxins. Non-toxigenic strains will not produce any precipitate.

questions.text: The deamination of ______ and the methylation of ______ both lead to the formation of thymine.
questions.solution:
The deamination of 5-Methylcytosine and methylation of uracil leads to the formation of thymine.

Thymine and uracil are pyrimidine bases found only in DNA and RNA, respectively. The only difference in the structures of these two bases is the presence of a methyl group in thymine. Thus, the methylation of uracil will form thymine.

Deamination is the removal of an amino group (NH2) from a chemical compound. Deamination of cytosine forms uracil. Thus, the deamination of methylated cytosine (5-methylcytosine) forms methylated uracil, which is thymine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasms with arching of his back, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. Microscopy of the specimen revealed a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus. Which of the following describes the characteristics of the spores produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism based on the given clinical scenario is Clostridium tetani. It is a gram-positive, anaerobic, rod-shaped bacillus with spores that are spherical and terminally located.

Clostridium tetani has spherical and terminal spores, giving it a drumstick appearance.

  • The genus Clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli.
  • The spores are wider than the bacillary bodies, giving the bacillus a swollen appearance, resembling a spindle. Hence, the name Clostridium.

Classification of Clostridium based on the shape and position of spores:

  • Central or Subterminal:  Clostridium bifermentans, Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  • Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped ): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficile
  • Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani.

The incubation period of C. tetani ranges from 6-12 days. It produces an exotoxin tetanospasmin which causes muscle spasms usually involving the area of injury first and then the muscles of the jaw causing trismus or lockjaw. Gradually, other voluntary muscles become involved, resulting in tonic spasms. Any external stimulus can precipitate a tetanic generalized muscle spasm. The patient is conscious but may be in pain. Death usually results from respiratory paralysis.

questions.text: Sabin Feldman dye test is done for the diagnosis of _____
questions.solution:
Sabin Feldman dye test is done for the diagnosis of Toxoplasma gondii.

The test is based on the presence of certain antibodies that prevent methylene blue dye from entering the cytoplasm of Toxoplasma organisms.

Procedure:

Patient serum is treated with Toxoplasma trophozoites and complements which act as activators, and then incubated. After incubation, methylene blue is added. If anti-Toxo antibodies are present in the serum, these antibodies are activated by complements and lyse the parasite membrane, thus, Toxoplasma trophozoites are not stained. This implies a positive result. If there are no antibodies, trophozoites with intact membranes are stained and appear blue under a microscope (negative result).

The test may give false positive reactions in Sarcocystis, Trichomonas vaginalis, and Trypanosoma lewisii infections.

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient reveals nucleated red cells with perinuclear granules that stain positively with Prussian blue stain.  Which of the following is the cause of this finding?

choices.text: Membrane-bound precipitates of denatured globin chains

questions.solution:
Ring sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue stain. There are formed due to mitochondrial dysfunction leading to the accumulation of iron in the mitochondria in a necklace fashion around the nucleus. Ring sideroblasts can be seen in sideroblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, and lead poisoning.

Option A: Membrane-bound precipitates of denatured globin chains known as Heinz bodies are seen in G6PD deficiency. They are formed on exposure to high levels of oxidants. This leads to the cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains and denaturation to form membrane-bound precipitates. Heinz bodies when stained with crystal violet are seen as dark inclusions within red cells.

Option C: Accumulation of RNA residues is seen as diffuse fine or coarse blue dots in the red cells with Wright-Giemsa stain. This is known as basophilic stippling and is commonly seen in lead poisoning. 

Option D: The persistence of active ribosomes that make hemoglobin in a young red cell gives the cytoplasm a bluish hue and is known as polychromatophilia.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with an obstetric score of G2P1L1 was diagnosed with gestational diabetes at 26 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen due to this condition?

choices.text: Gross congenital anomalies in the fetus
Baby that is large for gestational age

questions.solution:
Gross congenital anomaly in the fetus is seen in the case of overt diabetes, not in gestational diabetes.

The first trimester is the period of organogenesis. Hyperglycemia and ketosis during this period cause excess free radical production leading to congenital anomalies in the fetus. The rest of the complications given in the above options occur in both gestational and overt-diabetic mothers.

Overt diabetes is a term used for pre-existing diabetes mellitus in pregnancy or diabetes mellitus detected for the first time during the first trimester of pregnancy.

According to the American Diabetic Association diagnosis diagnosis of overt diabetes is made if

  • The fasting plasma glucose exceeds 126 mg/dl
  • The 2 hours post glucose (75 gm) value exceeds 200 mg/dl 
  • HbA1C ≥ 6.5%

Complications 

Maternal

During pregnancy:

    1. Abortion: Recurrent spontaneous abortion may be associated with uncontrolled diabetes. (Option B)
    2. Preterm labor may be due to infection or polyhydramnios.
    3. Infection: Urinary tract infection and vulvovaginitis.
    4. Increased incidence of preeclampsia.
    5. Polyhydramnios: Large baby, large placenta, fetal hyperglycemia leading to polyuria, and increased concentration of glucose of liquor irritating the amniotic epithelium are probable causes. (Option C)
    6. Maternal distress may be due to the combined effects of an oversized fetus and polyhydramnios.
    7. Diabetic retinopathy
    8. Diabetic nephropathy
    9. Coronary artery disease
    10. Ketoacidosis

During labor: There is an increased incidence of:

  • Prolongation of labor due to a big baby.
  • Shoulder dystocia  Shoulder dystocia is due to disproportionate growth with an increased shoulder/head ratio.
  • Perineal injuries.
  • Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Operative interference

Neonatal and fetal complications

    1. Congenital Malformations
    2. Altered fetal growth in the form of macrosomia- Maternal hyperglycemia → hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the fetal islets of Langerhans → increased secretion of fetal insulin → stimulates carbohydrate utilization and accumulation of fat. (Option D)
    3. It can also present as growth retardation due to compromised maternal blood flow due to diabetes.
    4. Respiratory distress syndrome is more commonly due to prematurity
    5. Neonatal hypoglycemia
    6. Hypocalcemia
    7. Hyperbilirubinemia and polycythemia
    8. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy primarily affects the inter­ ventricular septum.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects of levodopa decreases by the addition of carbidopa?
questions.solution:
The incidence of cardiac arrhythmias is decreased.

Behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares and delusions are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral carboxylase inhibitors. This is because of the higher levels of dopamine formed in CNS.

The combination of levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor like carbidopa inhibits peripheral adverse effects of dopamine. This decreases the adverse effects like anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child was diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition and was started on treatment. When can the child's treatment be considered complete?
  1. There is no edema for at least two weeks
  2. There is no edema for at least 4 weeks
  3. Weight for length reaches - 2 S.D or higher
  4. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm
  5. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 13.5 cm
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 4.

A child with SAM may be considered to have completed treatment when:

  • There is no edema for at least 2 weeks +
  • Weight-for-height (or length) reaches -2 SD or higher or mid-upper-arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

Treatment: The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Phases: 

Initial stabilization phase :

(mnemonic: SHIELDED- Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia), Hypothermia, Infection, ELectrolyte imbalance, DEhydration, Deficiency of nutrients)

  • Focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions.
  • 2-7 days of inpatient treatment

Rehabilitation phase: 

  • Focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues
  • Takes several weeks

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (Blood glucose level<54 mg/dl): if symptomatic give 10% Dextrose IV 5ml/kg; Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (Formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care (“kangaroo technique”) or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal - Rehydration solution for malnutrition (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (4 mmol/kg/day) and magnesium (0.6 mmol/kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14 if there is presence of xeropthalmia.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding : Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day,100 kcal/kg/day, and 1 to 1.5 g protein/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal edema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: What level of structural organization of a protein is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures viz:

  • Primary
    • The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.
  • Secondary
    • The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.
    • Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.
    • Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.
    • Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.
  •  Tertiary
    • This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.
    • Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.
  •  Quaternary
    • It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein.

questions.text: Based on mechanism of action and effects, which of the following pairs is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is reserpine - inhibits prolactin release. Reserpine is a dopamine depletor. Use of reserpine results in low levels of dopamine (Prolactin inhibitory factor), and hence loss of inhibition of prolactin release. Hence, prolactin levels rise.

Chlorpromazine, metoclopramide and reserpine are enhancers of prolactin secretion.

Note: Drugs that inhibit prolactin release are bromocriptine and cabergoline.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy had rheumatic fever with carditis. He now has persistent mitral regurgitation. What is the age till which he should receive penicillin prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
A 14-year-old boy with a history of rheumatic fever with carditis and persistent mitral regurgitation requires penicillin prophylaxis till the age of 40 years.

The key to controlling acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is secondary prevention with antibiotics. This prevents infections with group A Streptococci and further worsening of the heart disease. The antibiotics used for this purpose are:

  • Benzathine penicillin G, 1.2 million units given once every 4 weeks
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin (in patients allergic to penicillin)

5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis and residual heart disease (persistent valvular disease)

10 years or until 40 years of age (whichever is longer), sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

questions.text:
Which of the following transporters/ enzymes are involved in the transport of iron across the apical membrane?
  1. Ferroportin
  2. Divalent metal transporter - 1
  3. Hephaestin
  4. Transferrin
  5. Heme carrier protein 1
  6. Duodenal cytochrome B
questions.solution:
Iron is transported across the apical/luminal membrane with the help of divalent metal transporter - 1, duodenal cytochrome B and heme transporter. They help in the absorption of iron from the duodenum into the enterocyte.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron in our gut exists in 2 forms, they are non-heme and heme iron. Luminal non-heme iron is mostly in the Fe3+ (ferric) state and is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases such as duodenal cytochrome B. Fe2+ iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). Heme iron is moved across the apical membrane into the cytoplasm through heme transporters such as heme carrier protein 1 and heme oxygenase 2.

Given below is an image of iron absorption that shows divalent metal transporter-1 protein in intestinal mucosal cells.

In the duodenal cells, Fe2+ iron can be transported to the blood or stored as mucosal iron. Fe2+ form of iron is transported from the cytoplasm into circulation by the protein ferroportin (Option 1). A protein called hephaestin (Hp) (Option 3) is associated with ferroportin 1. It is not a transporter itself, but it facilitates basolateral transport.

Once in circulation, Fe2+ is again oxidized back to Fe3+ iron by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The newly absorbed Fe3+ iron binds rapidly to transferrin (Option 4) and is delivered to red cell progenitors in the marrow. Hepcidin is a protein secreted from the liver that plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: Which of the following structures are most likely to be compressed in the process shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a carotid sleeper hold. Carotid arteries and jugular veins are compressed in this type of strangulation. 

In carotid sleeper hold, also known as lateral vascular neck restraint, the arm is placed about the neck with the antecubital fossa centered at the midline of the neck. The free hand grips the wrist and the arm is pulled backward, compressing carotid arteries and jugular veins, but not vertebral arteries or trachea. The person loses consciousness in 10 to 15 seconds and regains consciousness within 10 to 20 seconds upon releasing the pressure. Here, the neck structures are not damaged. Death may rarely occur due to catecholamine release or hypoxia which can trigger myocardial infarction or dysrhythmias in patients with ischemic heart disease.

Carotid hold also known as choke hold or bar arm involves placing the forearm straight across the front of the neck. The free hand grips the wrist and pulls it back causing obstruction of the airway and carotids resulting in immediate unconsciousness. Fracture of the hyoid or larynx can occur with greater force. Pressure on the carotid bodies can cause sudden cardiac arrest.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was brought with complaints of one episode of seizure, vomiting, and poor feeding. Investigations revealed increased levels of lactate in blood and cerebrospinal fluid. The deficiency of which of the following enzymes leads to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with elevated levels of lactate in blood and cerebrospinal fluid suggestive of congenital lactic acidosis. The deficiency of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex leads to this condition.

Congenital lactic acidosis is an inborn error of metabolism that often presents in infancy with lethargy, vomiting, tachypnea, and poor feeding. Other severe symptoms include hypotonia and seizures. Investigations show a high level of lactate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine (lactic acidosis).

Causes of lactic acidosis include mitochondrial disorders, deficiency of PDH enzyme/vitamin B12, mercury, and arsenite poisoning.

The pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. It has three enzyme components that include:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

The cofactors for PDH complex are:

  • Thiamine diphosphate
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is : Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Pyruvate Dehydrogenase is regulated by end-product inhibition & covalent modification

  • PDH is inhibited by its products, acetyl-CoA, and NADH.
  • Phosphorylation of the multienzyme complex by a kinase results in decreased activity.
    • The kinase is activated by increases in the [ATP]/[ADP], [acetyl-CoA]/[CoA], and [NADH]/[NAD+] ratios.
  • Dephosphorylation, catalyzed by a phosphatase, causes an increase in the activity of PDH.

Thus, pyruvate dehydrogenase, and therefore glycolysis, is inhibited when there is adequate ATP available and when fatty acids are being oxidized. In adipose tissue, the enzyme is activated in response to insulin.

Clinical aspects:

  • Arsenite and mercuric ions react with the -SH groups of lipoic acid and inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • Dietary thiamine deficiency inhibits PDH. Therefore, chronic alcoholics may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis.
  • Patients with inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency present with lactic acidosis, particularly after a glucose load, and present with neurological disturbances.

Other options:

Options B and C: Inherited aldolase A deficiency and pyruvate kinase deficiency in erythrocytes cause hemolytic anemia.

Option D: Aldolase B cleaves fructose-1-phosphate. In the deficiency of aldolase B, hereditary fructose intolerance develops which is characterized by profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after consumption of sucrose, which yields fructose in digestion. This can lead to fructose-induced hypoglycemia.

4 Lactic acid dehydrogenase Pyruvate to lactate(Anaerobic glycolysis)

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a painless lump on the upper side of her left breast following an injury.  Skin tethering and nipple retraction are also present. Which of the following is best suited to differentiate whether this lump is due to traumatic fat necrosis or due to carcinoma?
questions.solution:
A biopsy is required to differentiate traumatic fat necrosis from carcinoma of the breast.

Traumatic fat necrosis mimics breast carcinoma. As it may present with:

  • Skin tethering
  • Nipple retraction
  • Lump in the breast(often painless).
  • Mammographic densities or calcifications

Histologically, fat necrosis is composed of lipid-laden macrophages, scar tissue, and chronic inflammatory cells.

Grossly ill-defined, firm, gray-white nodules containing small chalky-white foci are seen.

The mammogram shows egg-shell calcification. It has no malignant potential.

Note: A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump and biopsy is required for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child who was unresponsive and cyanotic was brought to the emergency. Which of the following is the recommended site to check for pulselessness before initiating CPR?
questions.solution:
The brachial artery is palpated in infants to check for pulselessness before initiating CPR.

The pulse should be checked at the carotid artery for children aged one and above. 

The short neck of children <1 year of age makes the rapid location of the carotid artery difficult. There is a risk of compressing the airway while attempting to palpate a carotid pulse in the infant’s neck. Therefore, it is recommended to palpate the brachial pulse before initiating CPR in infants. The brachial pulse is palpated on the inside of the upper arm, between the infant’s elbow and shoulder. The inside of the upper arm is pressed with the index and middle fingers gently for no more than 10 seconds. 

Chest compressions in infants are given by placing two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below it if only one provider is available. The torso is encircled by the palms of both hands with the thumbs pointing cephalad and positioned 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum.

The depth of compressions in infants should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below the first finger
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands, thumbs pointing cephalad and positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth in infants (<1 year). 
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The heel of the palm on the lower 1/3rd of the sternum is applied during chest compression
  • The depth of compression is 2 inches or 1/3 the depth of the patient's chest.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths i.e. 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if the second rescuer arrives).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the muscle marked "A" in the image given below?

choices.text: Originates from anterior superior iliac spine
The aponeurosis forms part of pes anserinus
Abducts and laterally rotates the thigh

questions.solution:
The structure marked "A" is sartorius. It is innervated by the Femoral nerve (L2, L3).

The sartorius muscle is known as the tailor muscle and is also the longest muscle in the body. The word "sartorius" is derived from the Latin word sartor, which translates to tailor, due to the way the individual will position one's leg while working.

Origin: Anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it.

Insertion: Into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity (joins aponeurosis of gracilis and semitendinosus to form pes anserinus).

Action: Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh; and flexion of the leg.

Innervation: By femoral nerve (L2, L3, and L4)

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and discharging sinus in the neck. She has a history of evening rise of temperature. Which of the following investigations is preferred to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Smear examination of the discharge specimen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of swelling and discharging sinus in the neck, along with the evening rise of temperature is suggestive of tuberculosis of the cervical lymph node (scrofula). The preferred investigation to confirm the diagnosis, in this case, would be CBNAAT of the discharge specimen.

In cases of extrapulmonary TB, the demonstration of acid-fast bacilli on the smear is difficult because the bacillary load itself is low. For this reason, CBNAAT and liquid culture are the preferred diagnostic techniques for extrapulmonary TB. Other techniques such as direct smear examination, biopsy for histopathological examination, cytology, and biochemical examination of the fluid are adjunctive techniques. 

In the case of a presumptive extrapulmonary TB patient, if no specimen is available from the site but the clinical suspicion is high, it is termed as clinically diagnosed extrapulmonary TB, and the treatment is stated. The symptoms related to the organ system in question should be considered when diagnosing extrapulmonary TB clinically.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man from eastern India was referred with a history of two weeks of fever which did not respond well to antibiotics. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and abdominal distension with splenomegaly. A rapid antibody test with rk39 was found to be positive. A tissue smear from a splenic biopsy showed amastigotes. Which of the following is an oral drug that can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Miltefosine is the first oral drug against Leishmaniasis and it is registered for use in India.

Miltefosine is administered at a daily oral dose of 2.5mg/kg in two divided doses for 28 days. The side effects are short-lived and include nausea, vomiting, increased transaminases, and abnormal renal function.

This patient's clinical presentation of persistent fever, lymphadenopathy, and abdominal distension with splenomegaly along with the demonstration of amastigotes in tissue culture is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. A rapid immunochromatographic test to detect antibodies against rK39 recombinant antigen of L.infantum can be used on the field.

Medical therapy for leishmaniasis includes:

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate) - route IV or IM
  • If the initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used - route IV

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice - route IV infusion
  • Paromomycin (route IM) is as effective as amphotericin

Miltefosine is also the drug of choice for the treatment of post-kala azar dermal leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 26 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of absent fetal movements over the last week. Examination shows absent fetal heart sounds. The ultrasonographic image is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about the USG sign?

choices.text: It develops earlier with breech presentation than with a vertex presentation
It maybe seen within a few days of fetal death, but often takes 2-3 weeks.
It occurs due to shrinkage of the cerebrum
Early stages may just show loss of alignment, instead of frank overriding

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of intrauterine fetal death (absent fetal heart sounds, no fetal movements). The image shows Spalding's sign with irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another. The sign will develop earlier with a vertex presentation than with a breech.

It is usually seen within a few days of fetal death but often takes 2-3 weeks. It occurs due to shrinkage of the cerebrum and may just show loss of alignment, instead of frank overriding, in the early stages.

Spalding’s sign is suggestive of maceration of the fetus. Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis occurring after the intrauterine death of the fetus. The prerequisite for the process of maceration to occur is that the dead fetus should be in utero for 3-4 days and should be surrounded by the liquor amnii. If air enters the liquor amnii after the death of the fetus, putrefaction occurs instead of maceration.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Dietary deficiency of Vitamin C can lead to scurvy which can manifest as microcytic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. It is mainly required for the hydroxylation of prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. It also facilitates the absorption of iron by reducing it from a ferric to a ferrous state.

Hence, vitamin C deficiency leads to defective collagen synthesis, fragile blood vessels, and iron deficiency anemia. Other clinical features of scurvy include spongy gums, loose teeth, swollen joints, subcutaneous hemorrhage, and bone fractures.

Other options:

Option A- Glutathione, an antioxidant, is present in glutathione peroxidase. It helps in the destruction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.

Option B- β-carotene is provitamin A, found in plants. It helps in the formation of retinaldehyde which is utilized in vision. It also regulates gene expression and cell differentiation.

Option D- Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes like carboxypeptidases, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, the cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, etc. Chronic zinc deficiency causes stunting and increases the risk of respiratory and diarrheal diseases. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes abnormalities in zinc absorption.

questions.text: The term recrudescence in malaria refers to _______

choices.text: Recurrence of malaria due to reactivation of hypnozoites present in liver cells
Recurrence of  malaria due to the survival of parasites in red blood cells.
Reinfection with the same species of Plasmodium.

questions.solution:
Recrudescence is the recurrence of malarial fever due to the survival of parasites in red blood cells.

After the initial infection of P. falciparum and P. malariae, there can be a period of inactivity where no clinical symptoms are present. However, certain parasites remain in some red blood cells, although their levels may be below the threshold for causing fever or even below detectable levels under a microscope. When the number of parasites reaches a significant level, a new malarial attack occurs as erythrocytic schizogony resumes at a low level within the body. This recurrence of clinical malaria caused by persisting P. falciparum and P. malariae is referred to as recrudescence. Recrudescence can be attributed to a decline in the host's immunity or possibly due to antigenic variation. It occurs within a few weeks or months of a previous attack

Incomplete treatment of P. vivax and P. ovale infections can result in relapses. These two species exhibit two types of sporozoites: one group rapidly multiplies within hepatocytes to form schizonts, while the other group remains dormant. The dormant forms are known as hypnozoites and remain as uninucleated structures, approximately 4-5 μm in size, within hepatocytes for extended periods. When hypnozoites are reactivated, new cycles of erythrocytic infection begin, leading to fresh episodes of malarial fever. These renewed malarial attacks, caused by the reactivation of dormant exoerythrocytic forms, typically occur between 24 weeks and 5 years after the initial infection and are referred to as relapses.

The patient was hemodynamically stable and X-rays revealed a fracture of the medial epicondyle of the right humerus. The patient complained of the sensory deficit on her right palm and on examination, there was a loss of sensation over the medial one and half fingers.
