questions.text: An infant presented with a lack of tonicity of the abdominal wall along with a wrinkled appearance of the skin as shown in the figure. Further examination reveals the diagnosis to be Eagle Barrett syndrome. Which of the following is not a component of the characteristic triad seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Eagle Barrett Syndrome is also known as Prune Belly Syndrome (Triad Syndrome) and kyphosis is not a component of the characteristic triad seen in this condition

Prune Belly Triad includes:

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, hypotonic, and thin abdominal wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: A patient after a motor vehicle accident develops breathing difficulty. On examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side, and the trachea is shifted to the left. Heart sounds are normal. There is a dull note on percussion. The chest X-ray is shown below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, dull note on percussion, and the chest X-ray showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification is suggestive of massive hemothorax. The next step of management that can be done for this patient is intercostal drainage tube(ICD) placement.

Massive hemothorax occurs when more than 1500 mL of blood, equivalent to one-third or more of the patient's blood volume, rapidly accumulates in the chest cavity. This condition is typically caused by a penetrating injury that damages major blood vessels, although it can also be the result of blunt trauma.

In patients with massive hemothorax, the neck veins may appear flat due to severe hypovolemia, or they may be distended if there is a concurrent tension pneumothorax. If a patient is in shock and exhibits an absence of breath sounds or dullness upon percussion on one side of the chest, it suggests the presence of a massive hemothorax.

The initial management of massive haemothorax involves decompression of the chest cavity. A single chest tube with a diameter of 28-32 French is inserted, typically at the fifth intercostal space, just anterior to the midaxillary line.

Simultaneous resuscitation to restore blood volume is also advisable. This is achieved by establishing large-diameter intravenous lines, administering crystalloid fluids, and initiating transfusion of blood at the earliest opportunity.

The immediate return of 1500 mL or greater volume of blood typically signifies the urgent requirement for thoracotomy. Patients who initially show an output of less than 1500 mL of fluid but continue to bleed may also necessitate thoracotomy.

Needle thoracostomy and open thoracotomy are done in cases of tension pneumothorax. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, and hyper-resonant note on percussion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe breathlessness. He was referred from another hospital with the diagnosis of acute left heart failure associated with pulmonary edema.  On examination, his blood pressure was 220/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy revealed papilledema. Which of the following drugs is preferred to control his hypertension?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of severe headache, blood pressure of 220/120 mmHg, and fundoscopy showing papilledema is suggestive of a hypertensive emergency. Sodium nitroprusside is the drug infused in the scenario.

A hypertensive emergency is diagnosed when the systolic blood pressure is > 180 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure is>120 mmHg with the presence of end-organ damage.

Sodium nitroprusside is an anti-hypertensive drug. It acts by releasing nitric oxide that activates the guanylyl cyclase. It acts by dilating both arterioles and venules resulting in venous pooling and reduced arterial impedance. 

Sodium nitroprusside is used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and can be used in the short reduction of cardiac preload or afterload. It has been used in reducing blood pressure in acute aortic dissection. It is also used in the management of congestive heart failure associated with pulmonary edema that does not respond to other treatments. 

When nitroprusside is administered at a high rate, it can result in the production of cyanide. Cyanide is further metabolized to thiocyanate. On prolonged infusion, thiocyanate toxicity can also occur especially in patients with renal failure. Excessive concentrations of thiocyanate can result in hypothyroidism. The short-term side effect is hypotension. Nitroprusside can worsen arterial hypoxemia in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease because the drug interferes with hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and therefore promotes mismatching of ventilation with perfusion.

Other options:

Options A & B - Labetalol is a beta 1 and beta 2 receptor blocker with additional alpha-receptor blocking properties and esmolol cardioselective beta blocker (beta 1). Beta-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of acute pulmonary edema.

However intravenous esmolol is the preferred drug for hypertensive emergency in aortic dissection where rapid reduction of blood pressure within 5-10 min is essential. If there is no improvement in blood pressure, nitroprusside or nitroglycerin is administered. The target blood pressure is SBP <120mmHg.

Option D- Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker. It is used in the management of hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors recognize fungi?
questions.solution:
C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

The various classes of innate immune receptors are as follows:

  • Signals via inflammasome which activates caspase and IL-1

Mannose receptor is a soluble pattern-recognition receptor. All the others are surface pattern-recognition receptors.

questions.text: All of the following are included in calculating the qSOFA score except______
questions.solution:
The rapid bedside screening tool for sepsis derived from the SOFA scoring system is called the qSOFA score. A heart rate >90 beats per minute is not a component of the qSOFA scoring system.

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU).

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),
  • High respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min),
  • Altered mentation (GCS score, <15).

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify patients at risk of poor outcomes from sepsis.

questions.text: A patient presenting with poor appetite and weight loss along with a few episodes of hematemesis is diagnosed with Siewert type 3 adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the correct anatomical location of adenocarcinoma seen in this patient?

choices.text: Adenocarcinoma located 4 cm proximal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 3 cm distal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 2 cm proximal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 1 cm distal to GE junction

questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma located 3 cm distal to GE junction indicates the location of adenocarcinoma seen in patients diagnosed with Siewert type 3 tumours.

Siewert classification system is based on the anatomical location of adenocarcinoma which is in close proximity to the GE junction. Type 3 tumours are also called sub-cardinal tumours and are located 2 to 5 cm below the GE junction. These tumours are usually treated according to the guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma. Type III adenocarcinomas generally have a worse prognosis. Siewert types I and II tumours are treated similar to oesophagal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with the history of polyuria and polydipsia was diagnosed to be suffering from type 1 DM. What will be the effect of this condition on the free fatty acid(FFA) level in this boy?

choices.text: Decreased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to Low glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Decreased FFA level due to low glucagon: insulin ratio

questions.solution:
In type I diabetes mellitus, there is an Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state and hence glucagon: insulin ratio will be high. The level of FFA, in turn, is controlled by glucagon:insulin ratio. Glucagon increases the FFA level and insulin has the opposite effect.

Note: Low insulin state also causes increased fatty acid oxidation leading to increased ketone body production and ketosis.

questions.text: Identify the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image
questions.solution:
The image shows the drooping lily sign on the right side, a urographic sign observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

The drooping lily sign refers to the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole moiety due to an obstructed upper pole moiety.

 

Other options: 

Option A - Fish hook ureter: 

  • Bilateral Fishhook ureters ("J-shaped ureters" or "hockey stick ureter") describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy.
  • Right-sided fish hook ureter describes the appearance of the retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

The image given below shows right-sided fish hook ureter

 

Option C - Bouquet of flowers appearance: It is a characteristic IVP finding in the medullary sponge kidney. The ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification giving this appearance. It is also known as the bunch of grapes appearance.

The following image shows the bouquet of flowers appearance:

 

Option D - In vesicoureteric reflex, there is an abnormal flow of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract. It is seen in children. It is graded as the following: 

Grade 1: reflux limited to the ureter

Grade 2: reflux into the renal pelvis

Grade 3: mild dilation of ureter and pelvicalyceal system

Grade 4: tortuous ureter with moderate dilatation, blunting of fornices with preserved papillary impressions

Grade 5: tortuous ureter with severe dilatation of the ureter and pelvicalyceal system, loss of fornices and papillary impressions

The following image shows unilateral vesicoureteric reflex.

questions.text:
Identify the correctly matched CD markers.
  1. CD45 - leukocyte common antigen
  2. CD34 - mature B cells
  3. CD33 - NK cells
  4. CD21 - EBV receptor
  5. CD3 - mature T cells
questions.solution:
The correctly matched CD markers are as follows:

  • CD45 - Leukocyte common antigen (LCA) is present on all leucocytes
  • CD21 - EBV receptor is present in mature B cells and follicular dendritic cells
  • CD3 - mature T cells and thymocytes

Option 2: CD34 is a marker for pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and is positive in the cells of immature neoplasms such as lymphoblastic leukemias. Mature B cells have multiple markers such as CD19, CD20, CD21, CD23, and CD79a.

Option 3: CD16 and CD56 are the primary markers for NK cells. CD33 is marker for Myeloid progenitors and monocytes.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with pallor and abdominal distension. His hemoglobin is found to be 7 g/dL. The electrophoresis pattern shows HbA 45%, HbA2 5%, and HbF 30%. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
HbA 45%, HbA2 5%, and HbF 30% are seen on hemoglobin electrophoresis in Beta-thalassemia intermedia. 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to the precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains. Each individual carries 2 beta-chain genes and 4 alpha-chain genes.

β Thalassemia major is a clinical syndrome caused by homozygous expression of abnormal β-thalassemia genes in the form of β+/β+, β+/β0, or β0/β0. The etiology is similar to that described above. Briefly, there is the complete absence or only minimal synthesis of the β-globin chain. The predominant type of hemoglobin is HbF, with very low HbA levels and normal to mildly increased HbA2 levels. HbA2 (5% or more); HbF (up to 95%); no HbA. 

β-thalassemia intermedia is a genetically heterogeneous β-thalassemia variant of moderate severity. This category includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β+/β0-thalassemia. HbA2 (4% or more); HbF (up to 50%)

β-thalassemia minor (trait) is a clinical syndrome caused by the heterozygous expression of one normal (β) gene and one abnormal β-thalassemia (β0/+) gene. It can either be present as β+/β or as β0/β. HbA2 (4% or more); HbF (up to 5%). 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia, with a leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the origin of the malignant cell?

choices.text: Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

questions.solution:
The clinical features and peripheral smear are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). In CLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL):

The CLL and SLL differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world. The median age of diagnosis is 60 years. The most common genetic anomalies seen are deletions of 13q14.3, 11q, and 17p and trisomy 12q. Loss of tumor suppressor genes in chromosome 13 results in overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein BCL2.

The growth of CLL/SLL cells is confined to the proliferation centers (pathognomonic for CLL/SLL), where the tumor cells receive critical factors from the surrounding environments, such as NF-κB for cell survival, MYC for cell growth, Bruton Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) signaling pathway, etc.,

The tumor cells express CD19, CD20, CD23, and CD5. Smudge cells are also characteristic of CLL. Clinical features include easy fatiguability, weight loss, anorexia, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, hemolytic anemia, etc. CLL/SLL has a tendency to transform to a more aggressive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)  - this is called Richter syndrome.

The peripheral smear in CLL shows, small round lymphocytes (indicated by arrow) with condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells may get disrupted while preparing the smears, producing so-called smudge cells (indicated by arrowhead).

Factors with a bad prognosis include:

  1. Presence of deletions of 11q and 17p.
  2. Lack of somatic hypermutation.
  3. Expression of ZAP-70 augmenting signals produced by the Ig receptor.
  4. Presence of NOTCH1 mutations.

BTK inhibitors and BCL2 inhibitors are highly active targeted therapy for CLL/SLL.

Other options:

Option A - Centrocytes are the origin of malignancy in follicular lymphoma.
Option B - Diffuse large B cell lymphoma can arise from nodal as well as extranodal mature B cells.
Option D - Bone marrow progenitors are the origin of CML and AML.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used for chronic prophylaxis of migraine except:
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan has no role in the chronic prophylaxis of migraine. It is only used for the treatment of an acute episode.

Medication for chronic prophylaxis of migraine should be considered in patients with four or more attacks per month. The medications that are beneficial include:

  • Beta-blockers: propranolol, metoprolol
  • Anti-depressants: amitriptyline, venlafaxine
  • Anti-convulsants: valproate, topiramate
  • CGRP antagonists (monoclonal antibodies): eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab
  • Others: flunarizine, candesartan, memantine

Migraine is a primary headache disorder characterized by episodic headaches. The patients present with a unilateral, throbbing type of headache. The headache is preceded by a prodrome period characterized by mental fatigue, mood changes, and aura in the form of visual disturbances (zigzag lines in the visual field). The headache is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

Acute treatment of migraine is done with paracetamol and NSAIDs (naproxen, diclofenac). If this treatment does not bring relief, triptans such as sumatriptan or rizatriptan are given. They are agonists at 5HT1B/1D receptors and cause vasoconstriction in the intracranial blood vessels. Other drugs that can be given for the acute treatment of migraine are calcitonin-gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists rimegepant and ubrogepant.

questions.text:
A child who was bitten by a stray dog was immediately brought to the primary health center. He had an abrasion on his left leg with minor bleeding. Which of the following measures should be taken immediately in this case to stop the contraction of rabies?
  1. Wash the wound with soap and water for 15 minutes
  2. Irrigate the wound with cetrimide and chlorhexidine.
  3. Infiltrate the wound with rabies immunoglobulin
  4. Administer the cell culture-derived rabies vaccine
  5. Suture the wound immediately
questions.solution:
The wound of the child bitten by a stray dog should be washed with soap and water for 15 minutes. This is followed by irrigation of the wound with cetrimide and chlorhexidine. Since there is bleeding from the wound it belongs to Category III. Rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin should be administered.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

 

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient had to undergo a cesarean section in a hospital due to a complicated delivery. She was discharged on her 5th-day postpartum. How many visits by an ASHA worker is recommended in this case?
questions.solution:
As this case is an institutional delivery through LSCS, the patient would be discharged after 5-6 days from the hospital, therefore 5 visits by the ASHA worker are recommended here.

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs. 250 if she completes all her visits.

ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3).

In case a newborn is discharged from SNCU, then ASHA will receive a full incentive after completing the remaining visits. ASHA will do additional follow-up visits every month for low-birth-weight newborns up to two years, and SNCU discharged babies up to one year. For each follow-up visit, ASHA will receive an additional Rs. 50.

If the woman delivers at her maternal house and returns to her husband’s house or vice versa, the visits might have been done by two ASHAs at the two different places. In such cases, if each ASHA completes at least 3 visits, they will receive Rs 125 each. If ASHA completes less than 3 visits, they will not receive any incentive.

In the case of twins/triplets, then ASHA will receive twice (Rs. 500) or thrice (Rs. 750), the regular payment.

The payments are made to ASHA on the 45th day, subject to the following conditions:

  • The birth weight is recorded in the Maternal and Child Protection (MCP) Card.
  • Ensuring that the newborn is immunized with BCG, first doses of OPV and DPT/Pentavalent, and entered into the MCP card.
  • Enabling birth registration.
  • Both mother and newborn are safe until the 42nd day.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What is the best confirmatory test of the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Manometry is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a barium swallow, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a 'bird's beak' at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy is usually carried out to rule out cancer. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: An 85-year-old female patient presented with palpitations for the last 4 days. She is hemodynamically stable and the ECG done is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG, showing tachycardia with narrow QRS complexes, irregularly irregular rhythm, and absent p waves, is suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). If the duration of atrial fibrillation is >48 hours, rate control (metoprolol) and anticoagulation (dabigatran) are done.

In patients with AF of >48 hours duration or unknown duration, there is a high risk of formation of a thrombus in the left atrium. If the patients are cardioverted at this stage, this thrombus can embolize into the systemic circulation, leading to end organ damage, such as stroke. Therefore, for these patients, any of the following two management strategies can be followed:

  • Give anticoagulation for 3 weeks → cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks
  • Start anticoagulation and do transesophageal echocardiography → if thrombus is absent, do cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks. If a thrombus is present, then cardioversion is delayed by 3 weeks.

Direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin for anticoagulation. However, warfarin is the preferred drug if the patient has a mechanical prosthetic valve, advanced CKD or moderate-severe mitral stenosis.

Apart from anticoagulation, the most important aspect of the treatment of AF is rate control. The drugs used for this are β blockers (such as metoprolol) and calcium channel blockers (such as diltiazem and verapamil). Reversion to sinus rhythm can be done electrically or using medications. Pharmacological cardioversion can be done using ibutilide, dofetilide and amiodarone (class III antiarryhthmics) or flecainide and propafenone (class Ic drugs).

If on presentation, the patient is hemodynamically unstable, synchronized cardioversion is done.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of recent onset right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On investigation, he was found to have a mass in his brain as shown below. Histological examination of the mass is likely to show all of the following features, except:
questions.solution:
The MRI scan image shows a tumor arising at the cerebellopontine angle. The most likely diagnosis based on the image and the clinical features of unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus would be vestibular schwannoma. A bag of worms appearance is seen in the case of plexiform neurofibroma and not vestibular schwannoma. They are a result of the expanded, ropy thickening of multiple nerve fascicles.

Vestibular schwannomas are commonly known as acoustic neuromas. The term vestibular schwannoma is preferred as these tumors most frequently arise from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve and arise from Schwann cells.

Vestibular schwannomas are the most common cerebellopontine angle tumors. Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are highly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2.

Clinical features: Patients present with adult-onset sensorineural hearing loss, with non-pulsatile tinnitus. There is no relationship between the size of the tumor and the degree of hearing loss. 

Microscopically, they are compromised of dense and loose areas called ‘Antoni A’ and ‘Antoni B’ respectively. Antoni A is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central ‘nuclear-free zones’ ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed ‘verocay bodies’.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

Diagnosis: MRI is the imaging technique of choice. High-resolution T2-weighted imaging is the most commonly used sequence.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old African-American woman is at the risk of developing metabolic syndrome and has been suggested to switch to the Mediterranean diet which is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids. Which of the following describes the effect of monounsaturated fatty acids?

HDL - High-density lipoproteins
LDL - Low-density lipoproteins

choices.text: Increase HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Decrease HDL+ decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol
Decrease HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Increase  HDL + decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol

questions.solution:
MUFA (Monounsaturated fatty acids) causes an increase in HDL levels and decreases serum LDL and total cholesterol levels. Plasma triacylglycerols remain unchanged.

The Mediterranean diet is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids (from olive oil) and n-3 fatty acids (from fish oils and some nuts), but low in saturated fatty acids. It contains seasonally fresh food, abundant plant material, low amounts of red meat, and olive oil as the principal source of fat. When substituted for saturated fatty acids in the diet, MUFAs lower both total and LDL cholesterol and increase HDL. This may explain why the Mediterranean diet, is associated with decreased serum total and LDL cholesterol compared with a typical Western diet high in saturated fats.

Unsaturated fatty acids contain one or more double bonds. These are classified into monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA). Unsaturated fatty acids lower blood cholesterol levels by the upregulation of LDL receptors on the cell surface, causing an increase in the catabolism of LDL. Omega-3 (ω3) fatty acids also have an anti-inflammatory effect and decrease triacylglycerol levels.

Monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) contain a single double bond, Ex:

  • Palmitoleic acid (ω7)
  • Oleic acid (ω9)
  • Elaidic acid (ω9)

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) are divided into two types based on the position of double bonds (when counted from the methyl end of the fatty acid molecule)

  • ω-3 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the third carbon atom
  • ω-6 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the sixth carbon atom

PUFA lowers plasma cholesterol and LDLs, but HDLs, which protect against coronary heart disease, are also lowered.

questions.text: Which of the following chromatography techniques is correctly matched with its property used for separation?

choices.text: Hydrophobic interaction chromatography - selectivity for ligands
Ion exchange chromatography -  interactions with hydrophobic groups

questions.solution:
Gel filtration chromatography, also known as size exclusion chromatography separates proteins on the basis of their Stokes radii. Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume a protein occupies in a free solution. It accounts for both the mass and the shape of the protein. 

The correctly matched chromatography techniques are:

  • Hydrophobic interaction chromatography - Interactions with hydrophobic groups
  • Gel filtration chromatography - Stokes radii
  • Ion exchange chromatography - Charge-charge interactions
  • Affinity chromatography - Selectivity for ligands 

Types of Chromatography:

1. Gel filtration chromatography: Proteins with large and small stokes radii are applied to the top of a gel filtration column. On entering the column, the small proteins enter pores in the stationary phase matrix (included proteins). During the mobile phase flowing down the column, they lag behind the large molecules, which get excluded (excluded proteins). Proteins thus emerge from a gel filtration column in descending order of their Stokes radii.

 

 2. Ion exchange chromatography: Proteins interact with the stationary phase by charge-charge interactions. Proteins with a net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to negatively charged beads called cation exchangers. Proteins with a net negative charge will adhere to positively charged beads called anion exchangers. Nonadherent proteins flow through the matrix and are washed away.

Bound proteins are then selectively displaced by weakening charge-charge interactions. This is done by gradually raising the ionic strength of the mobile phase. It is shown in the image below.

3. Affinity chromatography is based on the high selectivity displayed by most proteins for their ligands. Enzymes are purified using immobilized substrates, products, coenzymes, or inhibitors. In theory, only proteins that interact with the immobilized ligand adhere. Bound proteins are then eluted either by competition with a free, soluble ligand or by disrupting protein-ligand interactions. It is shown in the image below.

4. Hydrophobic interaction chromatography separates proteins based on their tendency to associate with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups. Proteins with exposed hydrophobic surfaces adhere to the matrix via hydrophobic bonds that are enhanced by employing a mobile phase of high ionic strength.

Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presented with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and orthopnea.  On auscultation, a holosystoloic murmur was heard over the left 5th intercostal space, in the mid-clavicular line. Which of the following left ventricular pressure-volume loops is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Holosystolic murmur heard over the left 5th intercostal space in mid-clavicular line is suggestive of mitral regurgitation. The pressure-volume loop represented as 'D' corresponds to mitral regurgitation.

Changes in the pressure-volume loop in mitral regurgitation:

  • At the beginning of the systole, there is no true isovolumetric contraction.
  • As the ventricle begins to contract, the blood flows back (regurgitates) into the left atrium. As a result, the afterload on the left ventricle is reduced.
  • This results in larger stroke volume, and smaller end-systolic volume.
  • There is no true isovolumetric relaxation, because, as long as the intraventricular pressure is more than the atrial pressure, the blood continues to flow back into the left atrium.
  • During diastole, the increased left atrial pressure causes increased ventricular filling, thus increasing the end-diastolic volume.

The LV pressure-volume loops shown corresponds to:

A. Aortic stenosis: The aortic stenosis causes an increase in the ventricular afterload. This leads to a decrease in the stroke volume and a consequent increase in the end-systolic volume. In chronic cases, the ventricle hypertrophies and this decreased compliance presents as an increase in the end-diastolic pressure. The pressure-volume loop is elevated and steeper in this case.

B. Mitral stenosis: The reduced ventricular filling in mitral stenosis causes a reduction in end-diastolic volume (ventricular preload) and consequently the stroke volume. A fall in the afterload due to decreased stroke volume decreases the end-diastolic volume but is not enough to compensate for the fall in end-diastolic volume.

C. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation and backflow of blood into the ventricle cause an increase in the end-diastolic volume (ventricular filling) and thus increased stroke volume. There are no true isovolumetric phases as blood flows through the regurgitant valve whenever a pressure gradient exists across it.

D. Mitral regurgitation

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with numerous hypopigmented and hypoesthetic skin lesions all over his trunk and extremities. Examination reveals a thickening of the ulnar and popliteal nerves. What is the recommended time for starting chemoprophylaxis for his wife?

choices.text: 4 weeks after initiation of treatment for the patient
Immediately after diagnosis of the patient
2 weeks after initiation of treatment for the patient
After the completion of treatment for the patient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypopigmented and hypoesthetic skin lesions with thickened nerves is suggestive of leprosy. Chemoprophylaxis for the contact (wife) must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient. 

A single dose of rifampicin is used in chemoprophylaxis. Chemoprophylaxis for the contact must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient. This is done to avoid immediate re-infection, as this is the time required to make most patients non-infectious. 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to the following contacts:

  • A person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours or more per week for more than 3 months.
  • Close contact if the age is more than 2 years

Chemoprophylaxis cannot be given if there is/are:

  • Possible signs of leprosy
  • Signs of or confirmed tuberculosis
  • Liver or kidney disease
  • Pregnancy
  • Received rifampicin in the last 2 years

Children 6-9 years (less than 20kg) 150 mg

questions.text: During a routine dissection class, your professor asks you to identify the structures seen in the given specimen. Correctly match the following with their respective structures:

choices.text: 1- Putamen; 2- Globus pallidus; 3- Caudate nucleus; 4- Thalamus
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- Thalamus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Thalamus; 2- Caudate nucleus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- putamen; 3- Thalamus; 4- Globus pallidus

questions.solution:
The correct match is: 1- Caudate nucleus, 2- Thalamus, 3- Globus pallidus, 4- Putamen. The given image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia.

The basal ganglia constitutes accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Both the Putamen and external capsule lie lateral to globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

questions.text: A patient has a hematocrit level of 40% and renal plasma flow of 600 mL/min. Calculate the renal blood flow.
questions.solution:
The renal blood flow is 1000 mL/min.

The amount of blood pumped to the kidney is known as the renal blow flow and is about 25% of the cardiac output. The renal blood flow is directly proportional to the pressure gradient between the renal artery and vein. The relation of renal blood blood flow with renal plasma flow is as given below:

Renal blood flow (RBF) = Renal plasma flow/(1-Hematocrit)

= RPF / (1-Hct)

= 600 / (1-0.4)

= 600 / 0.6

= 1000 mL/min

questions.text: The histopathological examination of a lung biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most common manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The histopathology section shows golden-brown rod-like structures with knobbed or beaded ends known as asbestos bodies. This is indicative of asbestosis and the most common manifestation seen in this are pleural plaques.

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It occurs in two distinct geometric forms, serpentine and amphibole. It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs and may present with dyspnea and cough, usually after 20-30 years of exposure. 

Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes. Other asbestos-related diseases include recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, mesothelioma, and rarely diffuse visceral pleural fibrosis in advanced cases.

Asbestos bodies are a hallmark finding. They appear as golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods. These are formed when the asbestos fibers are phagocytosed by the macrophages and are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever, headache, and cough with scanty sputum. His chest radiograph shows patchy consolidation of the left lower lobe. The culture of the sputum specimen shows fried egg colonies. Which of the following statements are true regarding the causative organism?
  1. It can be cultured on PPLO broth.
  2. It has a rigid cell wall composed of polysaccharides.
  3. It belongs to the class Mollicutes
  4. The colonies can be demonstrated by Diene’s stain
  5. It utilizes glucose or arginine as the major source of energy.
questions.solution:
The causative organism based on the given clinical scenario showing fried egg colonies on culture points to Mycoplasma pneumoniae. It is devoid of cell walls.

Mycoplasmas are the smallest microorganisms that are pleomorphic and lack cell walls. There are 4 species that are of importance to humans.

  • Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Mycoplasma hominis
  • Mycoplasma genitalium

Mycoplasmas, which belong to the class Mollicutes, derive their primary source of energy from glucose or arginine. Ureaplasmas are an exception as they have the capability to hydrolyze urea. To cultivate these bacteria, complex media like PPLO broth are employed, consisting of agar, broth, and biphasic media with enriching substances such as yeast dialysate and horse serum. Penicillin and thallium are added to prevent the growth of other bacteria.

Mycoplasma colonies exhibit a characteristic fried egg appearance, with a central opaque granular region that extends into the depth of the medium, surrounded by a flat, translucent outer zone. For a detailed examination, the Dienes method involves cutting a block of agar containing the colony and placing it on a slide. A cover slip is then applied, onto which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried.

These bacteria primarily cause pneumonia and genital infections. Ureaplasma urealyticum possesses a unique ability to hydrolyze urea and is responsible for non-gonococcal urethritis. It can exhibit resistance to commonly used antibiotics such as tetracycline and doxycycline.

The image given below shows fried-egg colonies of mycoplasma.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia. X-Ray of femur showed Erlen Mayer flask deformity. Bone marrow shows cells with crumpled tissue paper appearance. Which of the following is accumulated in the cells?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features and bone marrow biopsy showing cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance suggest Gaucher’s disease. Glucocerebroside (glucosylceramide) is getting accumulated in the cells.

Gaucher's disease is a genetic disorder in which glucocerebroside accumulates in cells and certain organs due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase). It is characterized by the following clinical features:

  • Painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Hypersplenism and pancytopenia
  • Bleeding tendencies
  • Bone pain
  • Osteoporosis, pathological fractures, Erlenmeyer flask deformity
  • Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze palsy (seen in type 3)

Gaucher's cells - These are formed as a result of the accumulation of massive amounts of glucocerebrosides within the phagocytes. The cells have a fibrillary cytoplasm and give a crumpled tissue paper appearance.

Treatment:

  • Enzyme replacement therapy is available for type 1 disease in the form of:
    • Human recombinant acid β-glucosidase (Imiglucerase/ Velaglucerase alfa)
    • Taliglucerase alfa

Note: Neurological involvement is not seen in type 1 Gaucher's disease.

questions.text: The pattern shown in the image below is caused by:
questions.solution:
The image shows an arborescent burn/ filigree burn/Lichtenberg’s flower caused by lightning stroke.

It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two. The mechanism by which this pattern is formed is not yet clearly known.

Other options - 

Option B- A scald injury occurs as a result of the application of liquid above 60°C or from steam. The injury does not extend as deep as in burns. At the area of contacts, redness appears at once and blistering will appear within a few minutes.

The below image shows an image of a scald injury.

Option C- Joule burn is specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. It is found at the point of the entry of the current. It occurs due to the heat generated in the body from the electricity. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimeters in diameter.

Option D- Spark burns or flash burns are electrical injuries that occur due to intense heat that may result from flash-over-producing burns that resemble thermal burns.

There is an air gap between metal and skin in spark burns. It has central brown or yellow nodule surrounded by an area of pale skin. These lesions are small as pinpoints or deeply seated and contracted if the voltage is high or the contact is prolonged.

questions.text: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows trisomy of 21 which is seen in Down syndrome. Flat occiput is seen in Down syndrome.

Clinical features: 

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Flat face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephaly/Brushfield's spots (speckled irises)
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Dysplastic ears
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and a wider gap between first and second toes

 The following images show Simian's crease and Brushfield's spots respectively.

Other options:

Option B - Webbing of the neck and lymphedema can be seen in Turner’s syndrome (45 XO). The image below shows the webbing of the neck.

Option C - Short stature with polydactyly is most commonly seen in Patau syndrome or trisomy 13.

Option D - Disproportionately long arms and legs and gynecomastia can be seen in Klinefelter syndrome. Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY. This results from the meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with growth over the nasal aspect of the left eye. Initially, it was small but has now progressed to the size shown in the image below. The vision was 6/12 in the left eye and refraction examination revealed astigmatism. Choose the correct statement regarding the management of this case.

choices.text: It is best left alone for spontaneous resolution
Only medical management is sufficient at this stage
Limbal conjunctival tissue from the same eye can be used for grafting
Application of mitomycin C drops reduces recurrence with no complications

questions.solution:
The clinical case and image point to a diagnosis of pterygium with astigmatism, for which conjunctival autografting is an effective method of treatment after excision. Conjunctival tissue can be taken from the limbus on the same side or from the other eye for grafting.

A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:

  • cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)
  • head
  • body

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism.

Treatment: 

  • A pterygium is best left alone unless:
    • It is progressing towards the pupillary area
    • Causes excessive astigmatism
    • Restricts ocular motility
    • Causes disfigurement.
  • Excision: Simple excision of the pterygium is associated with a high recurrence rate, and should be combined with:
    • Mitomycin C drops- applied pre-operatively/ intra-operatively or post-operatively to prevent a recurrence. However, it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract, and iritis and should be used judiciously. 
    • Beta irradiation
    • Conjunctival autografting- limbal tissue from the same or other eye is grafted and secured with fibrin glue or sutures.
    • Amniotic membrane graft
    • Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty if the lesion is deep.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe vaginal bleeding not responding to medical management. An abdominal hysterectomy was performed. On post-op day 1 the patient was diagnosed with significant hemoperitoneum. A laparotomy was performed and the source of bleeding was identified as the Sampson artery. Which of the following structures is likely to have been improperly clamped during hysterectomy resulting in hemoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the round ligament which is supplied by the Sampson artery is likely to have been improperly clamped during the hysterectomy resulting in hemoperitoneum. The round ligament is the only ligament that receives a blood supply.

The round ligament originates below and anterior to the origin of the fallopian tubes. Clinically, this orientation can aid tube identification during puerperal sterilization. Each round ligament extends laterally and down into the inguinal canal, through which it passes, to terminate in the upper portion of the ipsilateral labium major. The Sampson artery or artery to the round ligament is a small branch from the uterine artery or ovarian artery and runs within the ligament.

The cardinal ligaments(lateral or transverse cervical or Mackenrodt's ligaments) are situated along the inferior border of the broad ligament and continue from the side of the cervix and lateral fornix of the vagina. They contain the uterine artery and uterine veins.

The broad ligament is a fold of the peritoneum that attaches the pelvis to the ovaries and uterus.

Infundibulo pelvic ligament (suspensory ligament) - attaches the lateral surface of the ovary to the peritoneum lining the lateral pelvic wall. It contains the ovarian vessels and nerves.

The sequence of clamping of structures in abdominal hysterectomy

  • The first clamp includes the Round ligament and Infundibulopelvic ligament(When ovaries are to be removed)
  • The second clamp includes the Uterine artery. 
  • The third clamp includes the Cardinal ligament and Uterosacral ligament.

In an abdominal hysterectomy, the cardinal(Mackenrodt) ligament is clamped before the uterosacral ligament.

The sequence of clamping of structure in vaginal hysterectomy

  • The first clamp includes the uterosacral ligament, Mackenrodt’s ligament, and descending cervical artery.
  • The second clamp includes the uterine artery and the base of the broad ligament.
  • The third clamp includes the round ligament, fallopian tube, mesosalpinx, and ligament of the ovary.

In a vaginal hysterectomy, the uterosacral ligament is clamped before the cardinal(Mackenrodt) ligament.

questions.text: When the membrane potential decreases from +35 mV to -40 mV, the voltage-gated sodium channels are most likely to be in which state?
questions.solution:
When the membrane potential is decreasing towards the resting potential (becomes more negative), the Na+ channels are most likely to be in their inactivated state (C in the given image).

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels have two gates— an activation gate near the outside of the channel and an inactivation gate near the inside.

Resting-State (Image A): The membrane potential is initially -70 mv and the activation gate is closed at this stage. This prevents any entry of sodium ions to the interior of the fiber through these sodium channels.

  • Activated State (Image B): When the membrane potential rises from -70 millivolts toward zero, it causes a sudden conformational change in the activation gate, flipping it to the open position. During this activated state, sodium ions can move inward through the channel. 
  • Inactivated State (Image C): The rise in membrane potential toward zero also produces a conformational change that flips the inactivation gate to the closed state. But this is a slower process compared to the opening of the activation gate. Therefore, the inactivation gate closes a few 10,000ths of a second after the sodium channel has opened and sodium ions can no longer move inside. Following this, the membrane potential begins to return toward the resting membrane state, which is the repolarization process.

The inactivation gate will not reopen until the membrane potential returns to or near the original resting membrane potential level. Therefore, the sodium channels can only open after the nerve fiber is repolarized.

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in central cord syndrome in the cervical spinal cord?
  1. Preservation of pain and temperature sensation
  2. Loss of fine touch and vibration sensation
  3. UMN type of weakness in the upper limbs
  4. LMN type of weakness in the lower limbs
  5. Bladder and bowel dysfunction
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, only bladder and bowel dysfunction is seen in central cord syndrome.

Central cord syndrome results from selective damage to the grey matter and the crossing spinothalamic tracts present in the vicinity of the central canal of the spinal cord. Causes include syringomyelia, intrinsic spinal cord tumors, and trauma.

The patients present with dissociated sensory loss — loss of pain and temperature (statement 1) with the preservation of touch and vibrations sensations (statement 2). This is because the pathology involves the central part of the spinal cord and the posterior column is relatively resistant to compression, owing to the thick myelination. The sensory deficit is present over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms — classically referred to as cape-like distribution.

Initially there is an LMN type of weakness of the upper limbs (statement 3) due to grey matter involvement of the cervical spinal cord. There is a loss of deep tendon reflexes and muscle wasting in the upper limbs. As the pathology enlarges and causes compression of other tracts, UMN type of weakness of the lower limbs (statement 4) develops. Bladder and bowel dysfunction and Horner's syndrome are also seen at this stage.

Syringomyelia is a developmental cavity of the cervical spinal cord that presents with the features of central cord syndrome as described above. Such symptoms begin in adolescence or early adulthood. Most cases are associated with Chiari type 1 malformation (protrusion of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum). MRI is done to confirm the presence and the extent of these cavities in the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with complaints of hard of hearing in his right ear. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears adherent to the promontory, prompting you to suspect adhesive otitis. You would grade the retraction in this patient as
questions.solution:
According to Sade's classification, tympanic membrane adherent to the promontorium is classified as  Grade IV retraction.

Sade classification of atelectasis/ retraction of the pars tensa.

  • Grade 1 – Retracted ear - Slight retraction of the tympanic membrane incus
  • Grade 2 – Severe retraction - Retraction of the tympanic membrane, touching the incus or the stapes
  • Grade 3 – Atelectasis - Tympanic membrane touching the promontorium
  • Grade 4 – Adhesive otitis - Tympanic membrane adherent to the promontorium

Another related classification that is relevant clinically is the Tos's classification which is as follows:

Tos’s classification of retraction of Pars Flaccida

  • Stage 1 – Pars flaccida is dimpled and more retracted than normal but not adherent to the malleus
  • Stage 2 – The retraction is adherent to the neck of the malleus and the full extent of the retraction can be seen
  • Stage 3 – Part of the retraction is out of view and there may be partial erosion of the bony attic wall
  • Stage 4 – Definite erosion of the attic wall with the full extent of the retraction being uncertain because it is out of view

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with complaints of purplish itchy lesions on his skin as shown below. On examination, thin white lines were present on the surface of the lesions. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C infection 3 years back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a purplish papular itchy lesion on the skin with Wickham's striae and a history of hepatitis C, which is suggestive of lichen planus.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. 

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles. There is an increased risk of developing lichen planus in individuals with a history of hepatitis C.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are the buccal mucosa and the tongue. Nail involvement can be seen as the thinning of the nail plate leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines, and linear depressions.

Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, irregular thickening of the granular layer, and compact hyperkeratosis.  Degenerating basal epidermal cells are transformed into colloid bodies. The rete ridges may have a sawtooth appearance, and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max Joseph spaces. In active LP, a band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Corticosteroids are the mainstay of lichen planus treatment.

Other options:

Option A- Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease. A typical bilateral symmetrical skin eruption consists of macules with a collarette scale in the periphery. It is seen in a characteristic "Christmas tree pattern" over the back and if a lesion on the upper chest may have a V-shaped pattern. The most common persisting sign is the oval salmon herald patch.

Option B- Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin. It is seen particularly over the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region as erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales. On removal of these scales pinpoint bleeding is seen. This is called as Auspitz sign.

Option C- Reiter's syndrome is also called reactive arthritis. Conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis after a genitourinary or gastrointestinal tract infection is the classic triad of reactive arthritis. A common dermal manifestation of reactive arthritis is keratoderma blenorrhagicum.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements about Kallmann syndrome.
  1. Associated with hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism
  2. Low FSH, low LH, low sex steroids
  3. Associated with precocious puberty
  4. Low GnRH
  5. Associated with anosmia
questions.solution:
Kallmann syndrome causes GnRH deficiency, low FSH, LH, and sex steroids. It is also associated with anosmia.

Kallmann syndrome results from mutations in proteins that are involved in the development of the olfactory bulb and migration of progenitor cells of GnRH neurons to their final site in the preoptic region of the hypothalamus. Thus, the patients present with anosmia, and deficiency of GnRH. GnRH deficiency causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (not hypergonadotropic; statement 1) — that is, low FSH  and LH (gonadotropins) and low testosterone or estradiol (sex steroids).

Patients present with delayed puberty (not precocious; statement 3). Males may present with micropenis because of a lack of testosterone even during infancy. Females present with primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual development. Other features that may be present are ocular manifestations (color blindness and optic atrophy), sensory-neural hearing loss, cleft palate, and cryptorchidism.

Male patients are treated with hCG or testosterone. hCG in males acts like LH and stimulates the Leydig cells to produce testosterone. Females are treated with cyclical estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct order of steps of Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) operation?
  1. Uncinectomy, Maxillary antrostomy, Bullectomy, Frontal sinusotomy, Sphenoidotomy
  2. Sphenoidotomy, Maxillary antrostomy, Bullectomy, Frontal sinusotomy, Uncinectomy
  3. Uncinectomy, Maxillary antrostomy, Frontal sinusotomy, Sphenoidotomy, Bullectomy
  4. Maxillary antrostomy, Bullectomy, Uncinectomy, Frontal sinusotomy, Sphenoidotomy
questions.solution:
FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that uses nasal endoscopes to enlarge the nasal drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses to improve sinus ventilation and allow access to topical medications. 

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

 Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

Contraindications to FESS:

  • Inexperience and lack of proper instrumentation.
  • Disease inaccessible by endoscopic procedures, e.g. lateral frontal sinus disease and stenosis of internal opening of frontal sinus.
  • Osteomyelitis.
  • Threatened intracranial or intraorbital complication.

questions.text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency room in a drowsy state after taking an overdose of his sleeping pills. His medical history includes insomnia for which he was on alprazolam. Which of the following medication will you administer to this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with benzodiazepine (alprazolam) overdose. Flumazenil is the drug of choice for this patient.

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site of the GABAA receptor. It antagonizes both the agonist (benzodiazepines) and inverse-agonist (beta-carbolines) of this receptor.

It is primarily indicated for the management of benzodiazepine overdose and the reversal of benzodiazepine anesthesia. 

Other options:

Option A: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used in the management of opioid overdose.

Option C: Naltrexone, another opioid antagonist, is used in the management of alcohol dependence, prevention of relapse in opioid deaddiction after detoxification, and weight management. It might cause liver failure.

Option D: Nalmefene is a pure opioid antagonist with higher potency than naloxone. It is used for the treatment of opioid toxicity and substance abuse.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria and her blood smear was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:

Treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy consists of Quinine. Quinine can induce hypoglycemia, so pregnant patients are advised to eat regularly while on this treatment regimen. During the second and third trimesters, area-specific ACT is the preferred treatment option.

  • For north-eastern states: Artemether and Lumefantrine

Chloroquine (option C) is used for the treatment of P. vivax malaria during pregnancy. Primaquine (option D) is contraindicated in pregnant patients.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent blood in stools and altered bowel habits for the past 3 months. After a detailed evaluation, she is diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma which is located at the distal third of the rectum and anal sphincters. There is no nodal or distant metastasis. What is the preferred management for this patient?

(APR-Abdominoperineal resection)
questions.solution:
Abdominoperineal resection with permanent colostomy is preferred for this patient. 

Abdominoperineal resection is the complete excision of the entire rectum, anal canal, and anus with the construction of a permanent colostomy from the descending or sigmoid colon.

Abdominoperineal resection is recommended for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas who satisfy the following conditions:

  • The tumor is located within 5cm of the anal verge.
  • Obtaining a negative distal margin (with a clearance of 5 cm proximally and 2 cm distally) is not feasible.
  • There is involvement or invasion of nearby structures, such as the external sphincter.

The most common immediate complication of APR is an intraabdominal or pelvic abscess. During pelvic dissection, there are many sites at which autonomic nerves that affect both sexual and urinary function may be injured. Dissection at the sacral promontory may injure the hypogastric nerves (sympathetic) if care is not taken to isolate them. Although urinary retention should be expected in the postoperative period, disruption to the bladder's autonomic supply may result in bladder dystonia, which may resolve over months or be permanent. In men, sexual dysfunction manifests as an inability to achieve an erection, a half erection, or retrograde ejaculation. 

Other options:

Option A: A high anterior resection refers to the surgical removal of the distal sigmoid colon and upper rectum. This procedure is commonly performed to treat benign conditions and diseases located at the rectosigmoid junction, such as diverticulitis.

Option B: Hartman's operation is indicated in elderly and frail patients who have poor anal sphincter function or postoperative incontinence. In this surgery, colorectal excision is done along with the closure of the rectal stump and permanent proximal colostomy.

Option D: Endoluminal stent is indicated in patients with obstructive rectal carcinoma and also as a palliative procedure. Only rectosigmoid and upper rectal tumors are suitable for stenting because, in low cancers, stent impingement results in tenesmus.

Transitional epithelium/Urothelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra. 

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with hepatitis B presents with multiple joint pain, abdominal pain, and discoloration in both hands as shown below.  On examination, his BP was 150/100 mmHg. Vessel biopsy showed fibrinoid necrosis and luminal thrombosis. ANCA is absent. Which of the following can be a possible diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
A history of hepatitis B, now presenting with multiple joint pain, abdominal pain, hypertension, and Raynaud's phenomenon, is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in this patient. ANCA being negative favors this diagnosis.

The microscopic examination of PAN shows segmental, transmural necrotizing inflammation. PAN primarily affects the small- and medium-sized arteries. The kidney, heart and GIT vessels are the most commonly involved ones. Lesions usually involve only part of the vessel circumference, and have a predilection for branch points. Because of these lesions, there can be impaired perfusion to the distal organs, resulting in infarcts and ischemic atrophy. 

During the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall and fibrinoid necrosis as shown in the image below. The phase of acute inflammation can also be complicated by thrombosis. Older lesions show fibrous thickening of the vessel wall extending into the adventitia. All the stages of the disease activity (acute to chronic) are often present in the same vessel. 

Patients typically present with hypertension (due to renal artery involvement) and abdominal pain and bloody stools (due to involvement of the GIT blood vessels). One-third of the patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis B.
