questions.text: An army recruit presents to you with complaints of pain and swelling in the right foot. He had joined army training 6 months back. An X-ray of his foot is given. Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most sensitive and specific investigation in this patient.

The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing a fractured neck of the 2nd metatarsal are suggestive of a March fracture. It is a type of stress fracture.

The image below shows the March fracture:

Stress fractures (or fatigue fractures) occur in a normal bone that is subjected to chronic repetitive stress. This initiates a bone remodeling process. When resorption occurs faster than replacement, the bone becomes liable to fracture. Such fractures are typically seen in athletes, dancers, or military personnel who have a strenuous exercise regimen.

Common sites for stress fractures include:

  • Metatarsals: 2nd metatarsal stress fracture is known as a march fracture
  • Calcaneum
  • Navicular
  • The distal shaft of the fibula is known as runner's fracture
  • Tibial shaft
  • Femoral neck, etc.

MRI has the maximum sensitivity and specificity to diagnose stress fractures. It can visualize lower-grade stress injuries before X-ray changes appear. A bone scan is the best investigation when bilateral, multiple sites have stress fractures. 

Most stress fractures are managed using an elastic bandage and avoidance of painful activity until the lesion heals. Stress fracture of the femoral neck should be managed by internal fixation as a prophylactic measure.

Other options:

Option A- Computed tomography (CT) scan can be used to diagnose stress fractures but it has a lower sensitivity when compared to MRI.

Option C- Bone scan is sensitive for metatarsal stress fractures but it is not specific. It is the best investigation in cases of bilateral, multiple stress fractures.

Option D- Radiograph is the initial investigation done in stress fracture but it is difficult to detect the early fracture line in the radiograph

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida at 37 weeks of gestation presented to the obstetric emergency room in uncomplicated active labor at 3 pm. She delivered a female baby at 5.30 pm. Which of the following statement is true regarding the diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Atonic uterus is not a complication
Controlled delivery of the head is tried

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given clinical scenario where the first and second stage of labor occurs within 3hrs is precipitate labor The true statement is that controlled delivery of the head is tried.

Precipitate labor:

Labor is called a precipitate when the combined duration of the first and second stages is less than 3 hours. It is common in multiparae. Rapid expulsion is due to the combined effect of hyperactive uterine contractions associated with diminished soft tissue resistance.

Maternal complications:

  • PPH due to uterine atony
  • Uterine rupture.
  • Uterine inversion
  • Infection
  • Amniotic fluid embolism

Fetal complications include Intracranial hemorrhage and brachial plexus injury.

Management includes hospitalization of a patient with a previous history of precipitate labor. During labor, uterine contraction may be suppressed by administering ether or magnesium sulfate during contractions but they are seldom effective. Delivery of the head should be controlled. Episiotomy should be done liberally. Elective induction of labor by low rupture of membranes and conduction of controlled delivery is helpful. Oxytocin augmentation should be avoided.

questions.text:
A young boy says that he noticed involuntary movements in the fingers of his right hand. These movements spread to the entire limb and lasted for a few minutes. He was conscious the entire time. Which of the following are the first-line drugs for this condition?
  1. Lamotrigine
  2. Valproate
  3. Oxcarbazepine
  4. Phenytoin
  5. Ethosuximide
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of abnormal movements starting in a part of the limb and spreading, with intact consciousness, points to a diagnosis of focal onset seizures with intact awareness. Lamotrigine, oxcarbazepine, and phenytoin are the first-line drugs for this condition. 

Focal onset seizures with intact awareness can have motor manifestations (such as tonic, clonic or myoclonic movements) or nonmotor manifestations (such as sensory or autonomic manifestations) but without impairment of the awareness. For example, a patient having a focal motor seizure in the motor cortex will note the onset of involuntary movements of the contralateral hand.

The synchronous electrical discharge can spread to adjacent areas in the motor homunculus and involve the corresponding body parts. Thus, abnormal movements may begin in restricted areas such as fingers or toes, and then progress to involve a larger distribution such as the entire limb. This is termed as Jacksonian march. Following the seizure, there is weakness in the involved region for minutes to hours. This is termed as Todd's paralysis. Sometimes the seizure may continue for hours or days and may be refractory to medical therapy. This is termed as epilepsia partialis continua. 

Focal seizures arising in the temporal or frontal cortex can cause alterations in olfaction, hearing, and emotional state. The patients may complain of unusual smells or sounds or feelings such as fear, depersonalization, and deja vu.

questions.text: A child is brought with fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. How long should a child be isolated in this case to prevent further transmission?
questions.solution:
Isolation is recommended until 24 hrs after the initiation of effective therapy in bacterial meningitis. Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis.

Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy.
  • Patients should be in private rooms, and hospital personnel should wear a face mask when they are within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.

questions.text: Tacrine and malathion inhibit the Acetylcholine esterase enzyme by binding to which of the following site/sites?
questions.solution:
Tacrine binds to the anionic site and malathion binds to the esteratic site of the Acetylcholine esterase enzyme and inhibits it.

Anticholinesterase drugs:

Reversible inhibitors

Carbamates Non-Carbamates
Physostigmine, Neostigmine, Pyridostigmine, Rivastigmine Edrophonium, Tacrine, Donepezil, Galantamine


Irreversible inhibitors

Carbamates Organophosphates
Carbaryl, Propoxur Dyflos, Echthiophate, Malathion, Diazinon, Tabun, Sarin, Soman


The AChE has two sites, an anionic site, and an esteratic site. Edrophonium and tacrine (Non-Carbamates) attach only to the anionic site and do not form covalent bonds with the enzyme. In contrast, organophosphates attach only to the esteratic site forming strong covalent bonds. Carbamates bind to both anionic and esteratic sites.

Reactivation of edrophonium­ inhibited enzyme occurs in < 10 min, because the interaction is by forming weak hydrogen bonds, and does not involve hydrolysis of the inhibitor, but only its diffusion. The reactivation of carbamylated enzyme (1/2 to 6 hours) is less than that of the synthesis of fresh enzyme protein. In contrast, that of the phosphorylated enzyme (in days) is more than the regeneration time. The phosphorylated enzyme may also undergo ‘ageing’ by the loss of one of the alkyl groups and become resistant to hydrolysis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady who is on treatment for hypothyroidism presented with several depigmented patches on her arms and fingers. Wood lamp's examination showed a milky-white fluorescence. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ivory/milky-white fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination is seen in vitiligo. Autoimmune diseases and vitiligo have a strong association, especially thyroid disease.

The loss of pigment from the skin is the hallmark of vitiligo, which can usually be easily seen by the naked eye in dark-skinned people. It may, however, be very difficult to appreciate in fair-skinned people because the difference in the color of normal and abnormal skin is hardly any. The normal function of melanin is to block and absorb light. Since there is less or no epidermal melanin in the vitiligo-affected patches, it cannot block the light emitted from deeper layers of the skin. The vitiligo-affected skin appears like a window of blue-white/ivory white light with sharp margins. Wood's lamp is hence helpful in the diagnosis of vitiligo, especially in fair-skinned people.

Vitiligo is classified as -

  • Segmental vitiligo- which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern
  • Non-segmental vitiligo- which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. 

One of the theories for the etiology of vitiligo is based on the clinical association of vitiligo with a number of autoimmune disorders like -

  • Thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism) - most common association
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Alopecia areata

Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Rarely there may be complete vitiligo (vitiligo universalis), or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, hyperpigmentation, along with normal skin present. The koebner phenomenon is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and the use of sunscreen. The topical application of corticosteroids is the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus have also bee successful. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin and selective ultraviolet B therapy are used as second-line treatment. In patients who do not respond to this treatment, surgical grafting techniques can be used, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non pigmented area. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Poor prognostic factors for vitiligo:

  • Positive family history 
  • Mucosal vitiligo 
  • Lesions over bony prominences
  • Isomorphic Koebner's phenomenon 
  • Non-segmental vitiligo

Leucotrichia, longer duration, and higher age at onset do not correlate significantly with progression.

 

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presented with jaundice and splenomegaly. Investigations were done and shown below. He is also found to have ankyrin gene mutation. What are the changes seen in his osmotic fragility curve?

Hemoglobin- decreased
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration- increased
Mean corpuscular volume - decreased
Red cell distribution width - increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, lab investigations, and ankyrin gene mutation are suggestive of Hereditary spherocytosis (HS). There is increased osmotic fragility and hence the curve will shift towards the right. 

Osmotic fragility is the measure of red blood cells to resist hemolysis when placed in reducing concentrations of saline solution. Normal hemolysis begins at a concentration of 0.5% NaCl and is completed at a concentration of 0.3% NaCl. It may be altered as follows:

  • Increased fragility is seen as a right shift in the graph. Here hemolysis begins at a higher concentration of the hypotonic saline solution.
  • Decreased fragility is seen as a left shift in the graph. Here hemolysis begins at a much lower concentration of the hypotonic saline solution (more dilute solution)

In hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility of the red blood cells is characteristically increased. These spherocytes lyse more easily in hypotonic solution than normal discoid RBCs due to the low surface area to volume ratio.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

The ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis. Mutations in the spectrin gene may result in severe forms of HS.

Patients usually present with anemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

The most common peripheral smear finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. This is, however, a non-specific finding. Other features seen are reticulocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies (dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs), marrow erythroid hyperplasia, and hemosiderosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to you with sleep deprivation, elation, and talkativeness for the last 4 days, but his social and occupational functioning is intact. He also complains of irritability and distractibility and gives a history of three episodes of major depression in the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features of decreased sleep, irritability, distractibility, elation, and talkativeness for 4 days with intact social and occupational functioning suggest an episode of hypomania. Since the patient has had episodes of major depression in the past, the diagnosis is bipolar disorder II.

Types of Bipolar disorder:

  • Bipolar I: Episodes of mania with or without episodes of major depressive disorder. At least one-lifetime episode of mania is required for diagnosis. 
  • Bipolar II: Episodes of hypomania with episodes of major depressive disorder. Major depressive episodes lasting at least 2 weeks and hypomanic episodes lasting for at least 4 days are required for diagnosis. A negative history of a manic episodes is needed for making a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder.

Mania presents with features similar to hypomania but for a duration of at least one week. There is a marked impairment in social and occupational functioning.

The age of onset for bipolar type I disorder ranges from, children of ages 5-6 years to adults aged 50 or above. The mean age of onset is 30 years. The lifetime prevalence of bipolar type 1 disorder is 0 to 2.4%, whereas bipolar type 2 disorder is 0.3-4.8%. Bipolar type 1 disorder is seen with an equal prevalence among men and women. Suicide attempt is seen in approximately 15% of patients affected by bipolar disorder. 

Lithium is used in the pharmacological management of bipolar disorder. Along with it, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines are also used.

Other options:

Option B: Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than two years in adults (1 year in children and adolescents). It is not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression and has an insidious onset. The low mood persists for most of the day.

Option C: Euphoria is an emotional condition marked by intense feelings of well-being, elation, happiness, and joy.

questions.text: A patient presenting with severe vasospastic manifestations of the upper extremity is planned for a cervicothoracic block. What is the most common approach used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
For cervicothoracic or stellate block, the most commonly used approach is the paratracheal technique

The correct placement of the needle and administration of anesthetic in a stellate block is usually promptly followed by an increase in the skin temperature of the ipsilateral arm and the onset of Horner syndrome. Horner syndrome presents as ipsilateral ptosis, meiosis, enophthalmos, nasal congestion, and anhydrosis of the neck and face. The complications of a stellate block include:

  • Intravascular and subarachnoid injection (Option D)
  • Hematoma, pneumothorax (the highest incidence is seen with the posterior approach)
  • Epidural anesthesia, brachial plexus block
  • Hoarseness due to blockade of the recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option B)
  • Mediastinitis following esophageal puncture may occur rarely, particularly if a left-sided approach is taken (Option C)
A cervicothoracic block or a stellate block is used for patients with head, neck, arm, and upper chest pain as their sympathetic innervation is derived from four cervical ganglia, the largest being the stellate ganglion. The indications for this procedure include:
  • posttraumatic stress disorder
  • severe vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause
  • vasospastic disorders of the upper extremity
  • refractory ventricular tachycardia

The most commonly used approach is the paratracheal technique, though an oblique or posterior approach can also be used. The point of injection of anesthetic is based on the following relations of the stellate ganglion:

  • posterior to the origin of the vertebral artery from the subclavian artery
  • anterior to the longus colli muscle and the first rib
  • anterolateral to the prevertebral fascia
  • medial to the scalene muscles

questions.text: In a healthy adult, the serum potassium level remains within the normal range despite excessive dietary intake of potassium. Which of the following is the primary site of this regulation?
questions.solution:
The distal tubule and collecting ducts are the primary sites of the regulation of K+ excretion based on dietary intake.

The renal mechanisms that maintain the extracellular K+ concentration despite wide variations in dietary intake is known as external potassium balance. A combination of filtration, reabsorption, and secretion regulates the urinary excretion of potassium.

In the kidney, K+ is freely filtered across the glomerular capillaries since it is not bound to plasma proteins. 65% of the filtered K+ is reabsorbed by the proximal convoluted tubule while another 25 - 30% is reabsorbed at the loop of Henle. The amount of reabsorption occurring at these two sites is relatively constant. The regulation of K+ excretion depending on the dietary intake of potassium occurs mainly at the distal tubule and collecting ducts as follows:

  • In the case of high dietary intake, there is an increase in the secretion of K+ into the lumen via the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the basolateral membrane and passive diffusion into the tubular fluid.
  • In the case of low dietary intake, there is a decrease in the secretion of K+ and increased reabsorption instead.

questions.text:
A patient presents with cyanosis and PaO2 of 70 mmHg. Despite giving 100% FiO2, the PaO2 does not improve. Which of the following can be likely causes?
  1. Pulmonary atelectasis
  2. Hypoventilation
  3. Interstitial lung disease
  4. Tetralogy of Fallot
  5. Atmospheric hypoxia
questions.solution:
Persistent hypoxemia despite giving 100% FiO2 can be due to atelectasis or tetralogy of Fallot.

Hypoxemia refers to decreased O2 concentration in the arterial blood. This is in contrast to the term hypoxia, which is used when reduced O2 is being delivered to the tissues. Hypoxemia can cause hypoxia, but certain types of hypoxia (such as anemic hypoxia) may occur without hypoxemia. One of the first things that is done for treatment when a patient presents with hypoxemia is the administration of oxygen. Despite this, sometimes the concentration of O2 in the arterial blood may not increase. This occurs in the following conditions:

  • Intrapulmonary right-to-left shunting occurs when there is perfusion of non-ventilated regions of the lung. The blood that goes to non-ventilated alveoli is not oxygenated. It mixes with the oxygenated blood in the pulmonary veins, thus bringing down the O2 concentration of the blood. This is seen in conditions like pulmonary atelectasis.
  • Extrapulmonary right-to-left shunting occurs in congenital heart diseases such as tetralogy of Fallot, transposition of great arteries, ASD, VSD, PDA, and Eisenmenger's syndrome. 

Other options:

In atmospheric hypoxia (statement 5), 100% FiO2 will correct the deficiency of O2 in the environment and quickly correct the hypoxemia. In hypoventilation (statement 2) and interstitial lung disease (statement 3), 100% FiO2 will increase the partial pressure of O2 in the alveoli much more than atmospheric air. This increases the gradient of oxygen across the alveoli, leading to the diffusion of more oxygen into the bloodstream and the correction of hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best clinical indicator to monitor the adequacy of therapy for a patient with shock?
questions.solution:
The urine output is the best clinical indicator to monitor the adequacy of therapy for a patient with shock.

The level of consciousness is an important marker of cerebral perfusion, however, brain perfusion is maintained until the very late stages of shock. Hence, it is a poor marker of the adequacy of resuscitation.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the phases of damage control surgery.
  1. Re-exploration to perform a definitive repair of all injuries.
  2. Normalisation of biochemical and physiological parameters in the ICU.
  3. Rapid sequence induction of anesthesia and intubation followed by movement to the operating theatre.
  4. Immediate laparotomy with temporary wound closure.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C: 3,4,2,1

The correct sequence of phases of damage control surgery (DCS) are:

3. Rapid sequence induction of anesthesia and intubation followed by movement to the operating theatre.

4. Immediate laparotomy with temporary wound closure.

2. Normalisation of biochemical and physiological parameters in the ICU.

1. Re-exploration to perform a definitive repair of all injuries 

The aim of the DCS is to restore physiology over anatomy. It is applied to trauma patients with combined vascular and visceral injuries.

The phases are:

  • Phase 1 involves recognition of the severity of the injury. Here,rapid-sequence induction of anesthesia and intubation is done. This is followed by early rewarming and prompt movement of the patient to the operating theatre.

  • Phase 2 involves performing immediate laparotomy. Here, the focus is to control bleeding and contamination. Abdominal packing and temporary wound closure are done.

  • Phase 3 involves movement to the intensive care unit (ICU). The aim is to normalize the biochemical and physiological parameters.

  • Phase 4 involves re-exploration in the operating theatre. Here, definitive repair of all injuries is done. Multiple procedures on multiple occasions may be required.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: During a labor posting, you happen to witness the management of a patient with difficult delivery for which the senior resident performs the maneuver shown in the image below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: This is done for the management of shoulder dystocia
Turtle sign is positive in this condition
Maternal diabetes mellitus is a risk factor
It is known as Zavanelli maneuver

questions.solution:
The image depicts rotation of the posterior shoulder to 180º in a corkscrew manner, this is Woods corkscrew maneuver for shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign (Option B) may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes(Option C), post-term pregnancy, and multiparity.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia.

The correct sequence of shoulder dystocia drill is as follows:

  • Call for help and mobilize labor assistants, anesthesia, and pediatric doctors.
  • 1st line of management - Mc Roberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of thigh) in conjunction with suprapubic pressure application.
  • 2nd line of management - Woods corkscrew maneuver (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion). Other maneuvers like Rubin's, Gaskin's (all four's position), Hubbard, and Barnum's maneuvers can be attempted too.
  • 3rd line of management - Zavanelli maneuver (replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis) followed by cesarean delivery
  • The last line of management (Not preferred nowadays):
    • Cleidotomy(fracture of the clavicle of the baby) 
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

questions.text:
Identify the correct activity of the various relay points involved in the baroreceptor reflex when a patient suddenly stands up after lying down. ‘+’ Indicates activation and ‘-’ indicates inhibition

NTS- Nucleus tractus solitarius

CVLM- Caudal ventrolateral medulla

RVLM- Rostral ventrolateral medulla
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a sudden change in position of the patient from supine to standing causes peripheral pooling of blood and reduced blood pressure. Thus there is reduced firing of the baroreceptors which is characterized by  - Baroreceptor, -NTS, -CVLM, +RVLM.

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the hearts and blood vessels. They are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the respective vessels when there is an increased volume or pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. The receptors of arterial circulation include:

  • Carotid sinus - present in the adventitia of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid. Afferent nerve innervation is by a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve called carotid sinus nerve.
  • Aortic arch - present in the adventitia of the walls of the arch of aorta. Afferent innervation is by the vagus nerve called aortic depressor nerve.

The receptors of low-pressure system/cardiopulmonary receptors are:

  • Atrial receptors -  present in the walls of the right and left atria near the opening of the superior and inferior vena cava and pulmonary veins.
  • Pulmonary circulation receptors.

The afferents from the baroreceptors activate NTS  by releasing glutamate. The NTS in turn activates CVLM by releasing glutamate. The CVLM on activation releases gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) which is inhibitory to the RVLM. The RVLM is the major excitatory source of the sympathetic nervous system. As it is inhibited, there is sympathetic inhibition thus reducing the blood pressure. The NTS also simultaneously activates the vagal motor neurons thus causing bradycardia. Thus,

  • Stimulation of baroreceptors is characterized by +Baroreceptor, +NTS, +CVLM, -RVLM.
  • Reduced firing of the baroreceptors is characterized by - Baroreceptor, -NTS, -CVLM, +RVLM.

questions.text:
A young lady who regularly takes oral contraceptive pills came with a positive urine pregnancy test. Which of the following drugs might be implicated in contraception failure?
  1. Rifampin
  2. Ketoconazole
  3. Erythromycin
  4. Phenytoin
  5. Nevirapine
questions.solution:
1, 4, and 5 can be implicated in contraceptive failures.

Rifampin, phenytoin, and nevirapine are microsomal enzyme inducers. They significantly increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives which decreases their pharmacological action. This may result in contraceptive failure. 

Some drugs interact with DNA and increase the synthesis of microsomal enzyme protein, especially cytochrome P-450. As a result, the rate of metabolism of the inducing drug itself (autoinduction) and/or some other coadministered drugs is accelerated.

Different inducers are relatively selective for certain cytochrome P-450 isoenzyme families, e.g.:

  • Anticonvulsants (phenobarbitone, phenytoin, carbamazepine), rifampin, and glucocorticoids induce CYP3A isoenzymes.
  • Phenobarbitone and rifampin also induce CYP2D6 and CYP2C8/9.
  • Carbamazepine and rifampin, in addition, induce CYP2C19 and CYP1A1/2.
  • Isoniazid and chronic alcohol consumption induce CYP2E1.
  • Other enzyme inducers are chronic alcoholism, nevirapine, griseofulvin, and DDT.

While azole antifungals like ketoconazole, macrolides like erythromycin bind to heme iron in CYP450 and inhibit the metabolism of many drugs.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents to the ENT outpatient department with decreased hearing in both ears, often associated with a ringing sensation for the past few years.  The Rinne test was negative and the Schwartze sign is seen on otoscopy. Which of the following will be seen in her tympanometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical history, negative Rinne test and positive Schwartze sign is seen in active otosclerosis. Tympanometry will show low compliance near ambient air pressure (As) graph in this case.

Tympanogram is a measure of the Tympanic membrane’s compliance or deflection to change in pressure. There are 5 types of graphs seen:

  • A: Normal individuals. It is the most common graph in the general population. 
  • As: Seen in otosclerosis/Thick TM.
  • Ad: Seen in ossicular discontinuity/Thin TM.
  • B: Seen in perforation of TM
  • C: Eustachian tube Obstruction

Otosclerosis is bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy, menopause.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).

Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicates that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz knows as Carhart's notch. 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

Stapedial reflex: As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, the stapedial reflex is lost.

 

 
 

 

A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs have a low therapeutic index?
  1. Lithium
  2. Digoxin
  3. Diazepam
  4. Theophylline
  5. Phenytoin
questions.solution:
The drugs with narrow therapeutic indexes are digoxin, lithium, theophylline, and phenytoin. Diazepam(Benzodiazepines) have high therapeutic index

The therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio. The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI in the following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 or TD50/ED50

where LD50 is the mean lethal dose, TD50 is the mean toxic dose, and ED50 is the median effective dose 

Median lethal dose (LD50) and median toxic dose (TD50)

  • LD50 is the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die.
  • In human trials, TD50 can be considered. It is the dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
  • Larger the LD50 or TD50, the safer the drug. 

Median effective dose (ED50)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect
  • ED50 is the quantity of a drug that can produce the desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

The therapeutic window refers to a range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: A young person is brought to the hospital following a snake bite. The attendants have also brought the snake with them for identification. The image of the snake is given below. The poison of the snake is mainly:
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia is the first sign of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding epigenetic modification:

choices.text: It causes the alteration of gene expression without mutation
The acetylation of histone favors active transcription
Genomic imprinting is a phenomenon involved in epigenetic gene inactivation
DNA methylation is restricted between cytosine and guanine residues connected by hydrogen bonds

questions.solution:
DNA methylation usually occurs between cytosine and guanine residues connected by phosphodiester bond (CpG) island on the same strand.

Epigenetics is defined as heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. It alters gene expression without the mutation. Epigenetic modification can cause both gene activation and inactivation. If it causes gene inactivation, it is known as Genomic imprinting.  

The epigenetic modification includes:

  • DNA methylation is usually restricted to cytosines of CpG dinucleotides, which are abundant throughout the genome. CpG islands in promoter regions are typically unmethylated, and the lack of methylation facilitates transcription.
  • Acetylation and deacetylation of lysine residues in core histones which activates and deactivates gene expression respectively. Acetylation of histone favors active transcription.
  • Methylation of histones: Histone Methylation Mostly Makes DNA Mute.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first germ layer that is formed and the cells it originates from respectively?
questions.solution:
Endoderm is the first germ layer to form and it is formed from epiblast cells.

Epiblast gives rise to all the 3 germ layers through the process of gastrulation.

After the formation of the primitive streak, the epiblast cells migrate towards the primitive streak. When they arrive at the primitive streak, these cells become flask-shaped, detach from the epiblast, and slip beneath the primitive streak. This inward movement is known as invagination.

Some of the invaginated epiblast cells displace the hypoblast to create the embryonic endoderm. Endoderm is the first germ layer to form. Some of the invaginated cells then start occupying the space between the epiblast and newly created endoderm to form mesoderm. Cells remaining in the epiblast then form the ectoderm.

questions.text: In the capnographic waveform, which of the following phases represents the exhalation of the dead space gas?
questions.solution:
In a capnographic waveform, phase I corresponds to the exhalation of the dead space gas.

Capnography refers to the method of CO2 measurement as a function of time or volume. Normal capnography and its phases are shown in the image below.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: Exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community?
questions.solution:
The spleen rate is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

The spleen rate refers to the percentage of children aged 2 to 10 years showing an enlarged spleen. Surveys focusing on spleen enlargement exclude adults since various factors other than malaria can cause splenic enlargement in this population. The spleen rate is a commonly employed measure measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

The slide positivity rate represents the proportion of slides that test positive for the presence of malarial parasites, regardless of the specific species. It provides information on the trend of malaria transmission.

The annual blood examination rate is the percentage of the number of slides examined in a population. It is an index of operational efficiency.

The annual parasitic incidence (API) is a method of assessing the incidence of malaria within a community. It involves comprehensive active and passive surveillance, with confirmed cases determined through blood examinations. In India, regions with an API≥2 per 1000 population per year are categorized as high-risk areas, making them eligible for targeted vector control measures.

questions.text: Which of the following tests will be useful to differentiate between Staphylococcus epidermidis and Staphylococcus saprophyticus?
questions.solution:

Bile solubility and optochin sensitivity are used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci. They are both α hemolytic on blood agar but some species of viridans streptocci are non hemolytic.

questions.text: The period between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis is called lead time.

Lead time refers to the benefit obtained through screening and refers to the time frame between the initial detection of a condition through early diagnosis compared to diagnosis through alternative methods.

Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection in a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions can be detected routinely by using eFAST?
  1. Simple pneumothorax
  2. Cardiac tamponade
  3. Subcutaneous emphysema
  4. Renal injuries
  5. Free fluid in the abdomen
questions.solution:
Simple pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, and free fluid in the abdomen can be detected early by using eFAST.

FAST is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates Left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

It is a quick, consistent, easily transportable, and non-intrusive test that can be conducted alongside resuscitation. eFAST demonstrates high precision at detecting >100 mL of free blood.

Limitations of eFAST are:

  1. Operator-dependent
  2. Bowel gas and subcutaneous air distort images.
  3. Can miss diaphragm, bowel, and pancreatic injuries
  4. Is unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum
  5. Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma
  6. May need repeating or supplementing with other investigations

questions.text: Identify the acid-fast stained organism shown in the below microbiology spotter?
questions.solution:
The image showing filamentous, branching acid-fast rods is suggestive of Nocardia.

Acid-fast bacteria are those that retain carbolfuchsin even after decolorization with hydrochloric acid in alcohol. They appear red, while non acidfast organisms take on the color of the counterstain.

Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and produce urease. They have aerial filament fragments that break into coccobacillary cells.

They are weakly acid-fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin (routine acid-fast stain) and retain when decolorized with 1-4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

They cause nocardiosis, which is an opportunistic infection. The main clinical presentation is pulmonary nocardiosis with cough, shortness of breath, fever, cough, and weight loss. Inhalation is the primary route of bacterial exposure.

Other options:

Option B: Actinomyces are gram-positive filamentous non-acid-fast anaerobic organisms. The below image shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces.

Option C: Mycobacteria are non-branching, acid-fast bacilli. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain. 

The image below shows mycobacteria with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

Option D: Isospora Belli with modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain shows a large pink-colored acid-fast oocyst as shown below.

The procedure of Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast stain:

  • Fix smear using heat
  • Cover with carbolfuchsin. Stain for 5 minutes over direct flame. Do not permit slides to boil or dry out.
  • Rinse with deionized water
  • Decolorize in 3.0% acid–alcohol (95% ethanol and 3% hydrochloric acid) until only a faint pink color remains
  • Rinse with water
  • Counterstain for 1 minute with Loffler’s methylene blue stain
  • Rinse with deionized water and let dry

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was found to have elevated cholesterol levels of 345 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 42, and also had greatly elevated cholesterol levels throughout his life. The physician put the patient on lovastatin. After 2 weeks his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL. The nature of the elevated cholesterol in this patient is most likely due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has familial hypercholesterolemia due to a mutated LDL receptor. This type of type II hypercholesterolemia is the most common form of familial dyslipidemia. 

Lovastatin is an inhibitor of HMG-CoA reductase. HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors cause cells to decrease the rate of cholesterol synthesis. Lower cellular levels of cholesterol cause a decreased conversion of cholesterol to cholesterol esters (by the ACAT reaction) for storage and increased production of LDL receptors. An increased number of receptors will cause more LDL to be taken up by cells from the circulation and degraded by lysosomes. Thus, blood cholesterol levels will decrease. Blood triacylglycerol levels will also decrease but not to a great extent because LDL contains only small amounts of triacylglycerol. Also, the patient most likely is heterozygous for a mutation in the LDL receptor. If the patient were homozygous for such a mutation, then lovastatin would not reduce circulating cholesterol levels, as there would be no functional LDL receptors to upregulate.

Other options:

  • Option A: The patient does not have a mutation in HMG-CoA reductase, as that is the target of lovastatin, and if an HMG-CoA reductase mutation were to reduce HMG-CoA reductase activity, then lovastatin would have little to no effect.
  • Option B: A mutation in protein kinase A, rendering it inactive, would not affect intracellular cholesterol synthesis (as it is the AMP-activated protein kinase that regulates the HMG-CoA reductase activity).
  • Option C: An inactivating mutation in ACAT (Acetyl-Coenzyme A acetyltransferase) would not lead to a reduction of circulating cholesterol in response to lovastatin as ACAT is important for esterification of the cholesterol to its other utilizable forms.

3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: Out of 100 women who took oral contraceptive pills for contraception, 10 women got pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl index?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 5 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10. There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Hence, pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per HWY. 

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Which of the following serotypes of E.coli exerts virulence without producing any enterotoxin?
questions.solution:
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) exert virulence without producing any enterotoxin.

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using EAF (EPEC adherence factor) and LEE (Locus of enterocyte membrane) and causes effacement of microvilli. This leads to attachment and effacement lesions of intestinal cells. Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle forming pilus encoded by a plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island.

Other options: 

Option A: Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin or Shiga-like-toxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome. 

Option D: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following enterotoxins:

  • LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP
  • ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
  • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
  • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.

  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A patient with longstanding uncontrolled hypertension has been diagnosed with chronic renal failure. Which of the following will you not expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
CKD itself leads to a reduction in potassium excretion, causing its buildup. Thus, hypokalemia is not expected in a patient with CKD.

The measures used in the management of CKD and its associated complications include:

  • Antihypertensive therapy slows the progression of CKD, irrespective of the drug that is used. However, the use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs for this purpose has the added benefit of reducing proteinuria. Reduction in proteinuria also reduces the risk of progression.
  • Patients should be advised to limit their potassium intake by reducing foods with high potassium such as bananas. Potassium-binding resins such as patiromer can also be used.
  • Sodium bicarbonate supplementation may be indicated in patients who have chronic high-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Active vitamin D metabolites such as calcitriol should be given to patients with renal bone disease.
  • Hyperphosphatemia is treated with restriction of high phosphate foods such as milk and eggs, and with phosphate binders such as lanthanum and sevelamer.
  • Anemia associated with CKD is treated with darbepoetin after replenishing the iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12 stores of the body.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine. His father suffered from a similar condition and has grade 5 chronic kidney disease and is undergoing dialysis. Although a light-microscopy was normal, electron microscopy reveals the findings attached in the image given below. Which of the following clinical features /findings are expected in this patient?
  1. Macular flecks
  2. Posterior lenticonus
  3. Conductive hearing loss
  4. Hematuria
  5. Proteinuria
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy are highly suggestive of Alport syndrome. The clinical features expected in this patient are macular flecks, hematuria, and proteinuria. The correct options are 1, 4, and 5.

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is due to mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. The majority have X-linked inheritance.

Patients present with asymptomatic microscopic or gross hematuria, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities like anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal erosions. Proteinuria exceeding 1 gram per day is seen by the 2nd decade of life.

Light microscopy of the glomerulus appears normal during the early stages. As the disease progress, mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening may be seen, leading to glomerular sclerosis. Foam cells which are lipid-containing tubular or interstitial cells develop during the later stages.

Electron microscopic features include irregular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and splitting, giving a basket-weave appearance.

questions.text:
Which among the given muscles converge and interlace in the perineal body?
  1. Bulbospongiosus
  2. Deep transverse perenei
  3. Ischiocavernosus
  4. Levator ani
  5. Internal urethral sphincter
questions.solution:
Bulbospongiosus, Deep transverse perenei, and Levator ani are the muscles that converge and interlace in the perineal body.

The ten muscles of the perineum that converge and interlace in the perineal body are:

  • Two unpaired 
    • External anal sphincter
    • Longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Four paired
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Superficial transverse perenei
    • Deep transverse perenei
    • Levator ani

The perineal body is the central fibrous skeleton of the perineum. It is situated in the medial plane about 1.25 cm in front of the anal margin and close to the bulb of the penis. In females, the sphincter urethro-vaginalis is also attached to the perineal body. The perineal body has a pyramidal shape in males and a wedge shape in females.

The perineal body is innervated by the perineal nerve, the larger and inferior terminal branch of the perineal pudendal nerve. It is directed forward under the internal pudendal artery. 

The perineal body supports the pelvic organs in females and it may get damaged during parturition or childbirth. This may result in prolapse of :

  • Urinary bladder
  • Uterus
  • Ovaries
  • Rectum

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presented with neurological symptoms. The radiological image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI showing Dawson's fingers (white-colored areas perpendicular to the ventricular surface), points to a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS).

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which there is chronic inflammation in the CNS, with demyelination and gliosis. Patients can present with a variety of symptoms:

  • Sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pins and needles sensations
  • Optic neuritis, which presents as diminished visual acuity, decreased light perception, and periorbital pain which worsens with eye movement
  • Weakness of limbs, usually of the UMN type. Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic of MS
  • Facial weakness 
  • Diplopia due to internuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • Trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, and glossopharyngeal neuralgia
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction

Patients with MS report worsening of their symptoms after being exposed to heat. For instance, the symptoms may worsen after a hot shower or during a fever. This phenomenon is termed Uhtoff's symptom. It probably occurs because of the transient conduction block when the body's core temperature is elevated. Another feature seen in MS is Lhermitte's symptom. It refers to an electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back, into the legs. It is commonly induced by movements of the neck.

MRI is used for making the diagnosis of MS. The diagnosis of MS requires demonstrating that the lesions are disseminated in space (involving multiple areas of the brain) and in time (multiple episodes over a period of time). Dissemination in space is determined by evaluating the MS-typical lesions on MRI. Dissemination in time is determined by the coexistence of gadolinium-enhancing and non-enhancing lesions.

questions.text: A person has not drunk enough water for the past 2 days and excretes highly concentrated urine. Which of the following is least likely to be involved in creating a hyperosmotic renal medullary interstitium which is responsible for producing the concentrated urine?

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Of the given options, the vasa recta are least likely to be involved in creating a hyperosmolar renal medullary interstitium.

The vasa recta primarily function as countercurrent exchangers in the process of producing concentrated urine. Despite a large amount of fluid and solutes being exchanged across the vasa recta, the net dilution in the concentration of the medullary interstitial fluid is minimal. Thus, the vasa recta do not help create the medullary hyperosmolarity but prevent it from being dissipated.

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration in the renal medulla are 

  • Active transport of Na+ and co-transport of K+, Cl-, and other ions out of the thick portion of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the medullary interstitium. (Option A)
  • Ions are actively transported from the collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Urea (Option C) moves from the inner medullary collecting ducts (Option B) into the medullary interstitium via facilitated diffusion
  • Only small amounts of water diffuse from the medullary tubules into the medullary interstitium

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was treated for a high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma with radiotherapy. Since he was not responding, he was shifted to chemotherapy. After initiating chemotherapy, he developed erythematous rashes over the areas where radiotherapy was administered earlier. Which of the following drugs is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin can result in a radiation recall reaction where erythema and desquamation of skin are observed at sites of previous radiation injury. 

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • Myelosuppression 
  • Cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulin levels are decreased in Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Serum IgM levels are decreased in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. However, IgG is usually normal and paradoxically IgA and IgE are often elevated.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes. Normally, WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus helps in cell adhesion, migration, and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells. In WAS, there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood resulting in defects in cellular immunity. 

The clinical features of WAS are recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) expression in blood cells. IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Ig A and Ig E levels are high. Reduced-sized platelet is a typical feature of WAS.

questions.text: You have been posted as an intern in the labor room where you have to monitor the number, duration, and intensity of uterine contractions in a 34-year-old, G2 P1 with a term pregnancy. She has moderate contractions. How long do they last?
questions.solution:
Moderate uterine contractions lasts for 20-40 seconds.

  • Weak contractions: <20 s
  • Moderate contraction: 20–40 s
  • Strong contractions: >40 s

Uterine contractions have to be documented in the partograph based on the number of contractions palpated in 10 minutes and the duration of each contraction. The partograph has to be updated every 30 minutes. 

Uterine contractions are felt as intermittent pain per abdomen. They are associated with the hardening of the uterus. At first, they are not strong enough to cause discomfort and come at an interval of 15-30 minutes lasting 30 seconds. As labor progresses, the interval shortens. 

True labor pains are characterized by painful contractions at regular intervals, increasing frequency, intensity, and duration of contractions, association with 'show', progressive effacement and dilation of the cervix, the descent of the presenting part, formation of 'bag of forewaters' and not relieved by enema or sedatives. 

They have to be differentiated from false labor pains which are dull in nature, confined to lower abdomen and groin, not associated with hardening of the uterus, relieved by enema or sedative.

Braxton-Hicks contractions are painless, irregular, and do not affect the cervix. 

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A woman brings her 8-year-old son with the complaint that the child wakes up at night and walks around the room for about 15 minutes. Any attempt to communicate with him during the episode is unsuccessful. The child is unable to recall the episodes when he wakes up. Identify the brain waves that correspond to the stage of sleep in which this condition occurs.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of somnambulism (sleepwalking) which occurs during NREM stages 3 and 4 which is represented by high-frequency, slow delta waves. 

Somnambulism is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities without full consciousness. It occurs in the NREM phase of sleep. 

It is more commonly seen in children, with peak prevalence being between ages 4 to 8 years, and has a familial pattern. It usually resolves after adolescence and is rarely seen in adults. It may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk, or perform semi purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty. Upon awakening, they do not remember the sleepwalking episode (amnesia).

During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road).

Forms of somnambulism include:

  • Sleep-related eating - the individual may ingest food during the episode.
  • Sleep-related sexual behavior (sexsomnia) - the individual may engage in sexual activities during the episode

Management:

  • Reassurance
  • Maintaining patient safety during episodes
  • Avoiding sleep deprivation and alcohol consumption before going to bed
  • Antidepressants, relaxation techniques, and hypnosis may also be helpful.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of ropy discharge from his eyes. Moreover, on examination the following finding is present. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, and also the presence of ropy discharge points towards the diagnosis of spring catarrh or vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

  • It is also called as warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years.
  • It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge

Limbal VKC: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area.

  • Vernal plaques
