questions.text: A patient is given 200mg of a drug and 150 mg of the drug is excreted in 4 hours. If the elimination of the drug follows first-order kinetics, calculate its half-life?
questions.solution:
The half-life of the given drug is 2 hours.

In this case, the drug follows first-order kinetics. So the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration. The half-life of the drug remains constant in first-order kinetics. The rate of clearance is also constant.

The amount of drug eliminated and the drug that remains after each half-life is given below.

Half-life Elimination (%) Drug left in the body(%)
First 50  50
Second 75  25
Third 87.5  12.5
Fourth 93.75  6.25

In this case, 200 mg was given initially and 150mg is excreted in 4 hours.

So percentage of drug eliminated in 4 hours = 150/200 x 100 = 75%

75% of the drug is eliminated in 4 hours. It takes 2 half-lives to eliminate 75% of the drug.

Hence 4 hours = 2 half-lives. In first-order kinetics, the half-life is always constant.

Therefore the half-life of the drug = 2 hours.

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is bought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state at a bus station in Kerala. He is unable to recall his name, address, spouse's name, or any other personal information. His driving license from his wallet revealed that he is from Bangalore. Further investigation revealed that he got laid off from his job two days ago. He has no history of substance abuse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of dissociative amnesia with a dissociative fugue. 

Dissociative amnesia is characterized by extensive and severe amnesia with an inability to recall important autobiographical information. The amnesia is predominantly retrograde with minimal anterograde amnesia. It usually follows severe emotional trauma, interpersonal conflicts, and other stressful events, such as sexual abuse, loss of a loved one, loss of livelihood, etcetera. Clinically, the presentation is quite dramatic with significant impairment in social, personal, and occupational functioning. In order for a diagnosis of dissociative amnesia to be made, it is imperative to rule out substance use, and other neurological and psychological conditions that may lead to a presentation similar to dissociative amnesia. 

It is further categorized into the following types:

  • Selective amnesia: Ability to remember some of the events occurring during a circumscribed period of time.
  • Localized amnesia: Inability to recall all events in a circumscribed period of time.
  • Generalized amnesia: Failure to recall one’s entire life.
  • Continuous amnesia: Failure to recall successive events as they occur.
  • Systematized amnesia: Amnesia for certain categories of memory, such as all memories relating to one’s family or to a particular person.

Dissociative fugue is characterized by a sudden, unintended, and unexpected travel to a place away from home, or workplace, or another place involved in one's daily repertoire. It is usually brief, lasting few hours to days, and is generally reversible. It is commonly associated with dissociative amnesia. In addition to amnesia, these patients may also experience confusion, trance-like behaviors, depersonalization, derealization, and conversion symptoms. It may recur in some patients.

It is important to note that dissociative fugue was deleted as a major diagnostic category in DSM-5. It is instead declared as a subtype or specifier of disso­ciative amnesia.

Treatment of dissociative amnesia and dissociative fugue is mainly with psychotherapy. 

Other options-

Option B: Confabulation refers to the unconscious filling of gaps in memory with inaccurate, fabricated, and often implausible information.

Option C: Depersonalization is defined as the persistent or recurrent feeling of detachment from one's self. The patient may report feeling like an automation or like they are watching themselves in a movie.

Option D: Dissociative identity disorder is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states that assume control of an individual's behavior. It was previously called multiple personality disorder. 

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: Inhalational agent with most rapid induction and recovery among the given agents is
questions.solution:
Desflurane has the most rapid induction and recovery among the given options.

Blood gas partition coefficient/ Ostwald coefficient for blood–gas:

  • The coefficient is defined as the ratio of the concentration in blood to the concentration in gas that is in contact with that blood, when the partial pressure in both compartments is equal. 
  • It is used to describe the solubility of inhaled general anesthetics in blood.
  • The more soluble the inhaled anesthetic is in blood compared to in the air, the more it binds to plasma proteins in the blood and the higher the blood–gas partition coefficient.
  • It is inversely related to induction rate i.e. agents with high blood gas partition coefficient have slow rate of induction and vice versa.

Blood gas partition coefficient of different anesthetic agents:

Gas Blood gas partition coefficient
Desflurane 0.42
N2O 0.47
Sevoflurane 0.65
Isoflurane 1.4
Halothane 2.4

Thus xenon has a coefficient between 0.13 to 0.2 and has the most rapid induction and recovery followed by desflurane.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman complains of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A giemsa-stained smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows Trichomonas vaginalis and infection causes a frothy, greenish-yellow discharge. Curdy white discharge is seen in vaginal candidiasis.

Trichomonas is a protozoan that’s slightly larger than a leucocyte with four anterior flagella and a single posterior flagellum. It exhibits jerky or twitching motility.

Infection of the female genital tract causes the following symptoms:

  • Foul-smelling, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge per vaginum
  • Itching around the vulva
  • Dysuria and frequent micturition

The vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

The condition is treated with a single 2 gm dose of metronidazole or tinidazole. The partner must also be treated simultaneously.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding subacute thyroiditis?

choices.text: Thyrotoxic phase is followed by hypothyroid phase
Preceded by upper respiratory tract infection
Antithyroid drugs are given in the thyrotoxic phase of the disease

questions.solution:
Antithyroid drugs have no role in the management of the thyrotoxic phase of subacute thyroiditis. 

Subacute thyroiditis is a granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral upper respiratory tract infections. Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been implicated in this condition. This condition is predominantly seen in middle-aged women, and usually resolves without any sequelae.

Patients present with painfully enlarged thyroid gland and fever. Depending on the phase of the illness, it may present with features of thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. The natural history of the disease has three phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase: there is increased follicular destruction and release of thyroglobulin and thyroid hormones, leading to increased circulating T4 and T3 and suppression of TSH
  • Hypothyroid phase: after some days the thyroid hormone stores are depleted leading to hypothyroidism. This phase is characterized has low free T4 (and sometimes T3) and moderately increased TSH levels.
  • Recovery phase: The thyroid hormones and TSH come to normal levels as the patient completely recovers from the disease.

Subacute thyroiditis is treated with large doses of aspirin or NSAIDs. If there are severe local or systemic systems, then steroids are used. Beta-blockers can be used to treat the symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. In the hypothyroid phase, if the levels of thyroid hormones are too low, then levothyroxine might be required. However, antithyroid drugs are not given in the thyrotoxic phase.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with facial redness as shown in the image. He also complains of burning and tingling sensation on the skin which increases on sunlight exposure and wind. The redness of the lesion increases when he consumes hot and spicy beverages and alcohol.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows erythema and papules on the central face, which along with a history of triggering factors like sunlight, wind, spicy food, and alcohol points towards a diagnosis of acne rosacea.

Acne rosacea is a disorder that appears mainly in people within 30 to 50 years of age. The lesions are mainly present on the convexities of the face. There are mainly 4 subtypes:

  • Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea (ETTR): Patients complain of a gradual increase in facial redness. They mainly appear on the lateral cheeks, the ears, and sometimes the sides of the neck. This redness can be triggered by various factors like sunlight, wind, hot, spicy food, and alcohol.
  • Papulopustular rosacea (PPR): Patients complain of red bumps or pimples that are located principally on the proximal cheeks, central chin, nose, and central forehead
  • Phymatous rosacea (PR): Occurs in a patient with preexisting PPR. They complain of thickening of the distal nose with a prominence of pores.
  • Ocular rosacea (OR): Patients complain of dryness and gritty sensation in the eye.

Other options:

Option B- Acne vulgaris is commonly seen in adolescents. It is commonly seen in the face, but can also be present on the back and chest. The lesions may present as comedonal acne, papulopustular acne, nodular acne, etc.

 

Option C- Melasma is seen mainly in women. It manifests as hyperpigmented macules which are mainly seen in the upper lip, the malar regions, the forehead, and the chin and may be associated with the darkening of the nipples. The affected skin is brown in color. They are bilateral and symmetrical.

Option D- Systemic lupus erythematosus presents as cutaneous erythema on light‐exposed areas. It is a butterfly-shaped rash on the cheeks. The nasolabial folds are spared.

2. Embryonal

Rhabdomyosarcomas are malignant mesenchymal tumors with skeletal muscle differentiation in childhood and adolescence that may occur at virtually any anatomic site but are usually found in the head and neck, genitourinary tract, and extremities. It is classified into the following subtypes:

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Rhabdomyoblasts with visible cross-striations may be present. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina with cambium layer. It commonly affects children below 5 years of age.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma has a network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, resembling pulmonary alveoli.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults and has large, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells that may be multinucleated.
  • Spindle cell/sclerosing has fusiform cells with vesicular chromatin arranged in a storiform pattern or in long fascicles. Rhabdomyoblasts may be present occasionally. Collagenous, sclerotic stroma is more commonly seen in adults.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your OPD with lesions as shown below. The parent says he also had similar lesions in childhood. The lesions are present on the forearm, face, and flexures and are very itchy on the background of dry skin showing signs of lichenification. Grattage test or scratching reveals oozing of serous fluid. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image showing eczematous lesions on the forearm, and flexures. This along with the history of them being very itchy and being located on the dry skin showing signs of lichenification and a grattage test revealing oozing of serous fluid points towards atopic dermatitis as the likely diagnosis.

Atopic dermatitis can be divided into 3 phases: Infantile, childhood, and adult phases.

Infantile phase: The lesions of Atopic Eczema most frequently start on the face but may occur anywhere on the skin surface. Often, the napkin area is relatively spared.

  • When the child begins to crawl, the exposed surfaces, especially the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are most involved.
  • The lesions consist of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • Secondary infection and lymphadenopathy are common.

Childhood Phase: From 18 to 24 months onwards, the sites most characteristically involved are the elbow and knee flexures, a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper‐ and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification may be seen depending on the skin type on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles.

  • The sides of the neck may show a striking reticulate pigmentation, sometimes referred to as atopic dirty neck.
  • The erythematous and oedematous papules tend to be replaced by lichenification.

Adult Phase: The picture is essentially similar to that in later childhood, with lichenification, especially of the flexures and hands.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen simplex chronicus usually presents as an itchy plaque. Chronic itching produces secondary lichenification. It may be associated with the history of atopy. It is less likely to appear as oozing on scratching. A predilection for flexural aspect in childhood as in this case is not classically seen.

Option B: Psoriasis classically involves extensor aspect unlike flexures as in this child. Moreover, it is associated with silvery scaling and grattage reveals fresh bleeding points (Auspitz sign) and not oozing of serous fluid.

Option D: Scabies is caused by itch mites laying eggs in burrows made in the skin. The burrows are visible as serpiginous erythematous lesions. It classically causes itching more during the evening and involves lesions in the circle of hebra unlike flexures as in this case.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: The characteristic sign shown in the echocardiography below, is diagnostic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The echocardiography shows “swinging heart”, which is characteristically seen in cases with large pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion refers to the accumulation of excess fluid in the pericardial space.

Radiographic findings in pericardial effusion

Greater than 200 mL of pericardial fluid is usually required to become radiographically visible. Radiographic signs include

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (pericardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign
  • Serially enlarging cardiothoracic ratio

Echocardiography is considered the primary imaging investigation for the evaluation of pericardial effusion.

An anechoic separation of pericardial layers can be identified on transthoracic echocardiography when pericardial ﬂuid exceeds 50 mL. In a supine patient, the effusion will first appear posteriorly, tracking anterior to the descending aorta and left atrium. The parasternal long-axis and subcostal four-chamber views are typically favored for inspection of the pericardial space.

questions.text: An adolescent girl presents with the complaint of dropping objects from her hands during morning hours and during exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. EEG shows 4-5 Hz polyspike-and-slow waves that are enhanced by photic stimulation. What is the drug of choice for seizures in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome). The drug of choice for the seizure in this girl is sodium valproate. 

It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are most frequent in the morning with preserved consciousness. The jerks can manifest as dropping objects along with absence seizures. Sleep deprivation, alcohol, and photic stimulation act as triggers. The EEG shows 4-5 polyspike and slow-wave discharges. Levetiracetam, lamotrigine, and topiramate are the other alternatives used.

questions.text: A patient underwent a laparotomy for Crohn's disease. A 15 cm segment of the ileum was resected. On the 7th post-operative day, the patient developed an anastomotic leak. He continued to have 150-200 ml fistula output for the next 7 days. There was no collection of fluid in the abdomen. The patient is stable now. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Perform laparotomy and exteriorize the fistula
Conservative management and wait for the fistula to heal

questions.solution:
A 150-200ml of fluid leak from the enterocutaneous (ECF) fistula site can be classified as a low-output fistula. In this case, there is no fluid accumulation in the abdomen, and the patient's condition is stable, hence conservative management is typically provided to this patient, and the fistula is expected to heal.

In the majority of cases, fistulas close spontaneously within the initial 4-week period. Therefore, it is recommended to allow patients a minimum of 8 weeks for spontaneous healing of the fistula before considering surgery. However, surgical intervention becomes necessary in many cases, particularly when unfavorable characteristics are present.

An abnormal connection between the small intestine and the skin can occur due to various factors such as Crohn's disease (CD), radiotherapy, abdominal trauma, or most commonly, as a complication of surgery, either from an anastomotic leak or an unintended enterotomy.

The amount of fluid output from the fistula over a 24-hour period is crucial in determining its physiological impact on the patient's fluid and electrolyte balance and guides the management approach. Enterocutaneous fistulas can be categorized as low-output (less than 200 mL/day), moderate-output (200-500 mL/day), or high-output (greater than 500 mL/day).

Principles of Management of Enterocutaneous Fistula:(SNAP)

  • S - Elimination of Sepsis and skin protection
  • N - Nutrition – A period of parenteral nutrition may well be required
  • A - Anatomical assessment
  • P - Definitive planned surgery
CT scans are the preferred method to identify infected collections, and percutaneous drainage can be performed to address them. It is crucial to protect the skin since small bowel effluent can be corrosive. Nutritional support should include fluid and electrolytes, as they can be lost in significant amounts in cases of proximal fistulas. Additionally, carbohydrates, protein, fat, and vitamins should be included.

Decisions need to be made regarding enteral and parenteral feeding options. Enteral feeding has its advantages, but if the fistula is located proximally or has high output, total parenteral nutrition will be necessary.

Surgery is preferred when conservative management fails or if there is an additional complication. A significant number of patients with enterocutaneous fistulas (ECFs) also require the repair of large abdominal wall defects in addition to fistula surgery. Typically, the fistula is removed by surgical resection, and an end-to-end intestinal anastomosis is performed. Bowel diversion surgery is also done. The introduction of through-the-scope clips has improved the repair of recent injuries when sepsis is under control and the fistula is small in size. However, this technology has limited usefulness in curing long-standing chronic ECF.

questions.text: What is the preferred contraceptive pill in a lactating woman and when is it ideally started in a fully breastfeeding woman?
questions.solution:
The preferred contraceptive pill in a lactating woman is the progesterone-only pill and it is ideally started at 3 months in a fully breastfeeding woman.

Progesterone-only pill does not suppress lactation and hence it is the preferred contraceptive in lactating women.

Regular breastfeeding is effective in preventing pregnancy with a failure rate of 0.5%-1.5%.  This occurs due to prolactin preventing LH surge and ovulation. It depends on the frequency of the feed rather than the duration of the feed. Hence when the woman is fully breastfeeding, a contraceptive method should be used from the 3rd postpartum month and with partial or no breastfeeding, it should be used from the 3rd postpartum week.

Oral contraceptive pill(OCP) is contraindicated in a lactating woman because

  • They reduce the quality and quantity of milk.
  • The hormone secreted in the milk may harm the infant
  • Increased risk of thromboembolism

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms.

Fluoxetine is the longest-acting SSRI. Fluoxetine has plasma t1/2 of 48-72 hours. It is metabolized to an active product, norfluoxetine, which may have plasma concentrations greater than those of fluoxetine. The elimination half-life of norfluoxetine is about three times longer than fluoxetine (180 hours) and contributes to the longest half-life of all the SSRIs. Therefore, the level of the drug in the body falls slowly at a rate to which the brain can adapt when the dosage is reduced.

Paroxetine and sertraline are short-acting SSRIs and are associated with a discontinuation syndrome characterized by dizziness, and paresthesias beginning 1 or 2 days after stopping the drug and persisting for 1 week or longer.

Venlafaxine is a SNRI. All the SNRIs have been associated with a discontinuation syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following changes in the respiratory epithelium is caused by vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency induces squamous metaplasia in the respiratory epithelium.

Metaplasia is a reversible replacement of one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) by another cell type.

Tissue Metaplasia
Airways Squamous metaplasia: Normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. The condition may occur due to chronic smoking.   Also, a deficiency of retinoic acid may cause squamous metaplasia.
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: The presence of bladder stones may trigger metaplasia, where the normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium.
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: In patients with chronic GERD, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barrett's esophagus)
Cervix Squamous metaplasia: Due to the low pH of the cervix, the normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium.
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: In some cases, after intramuscular hemorrhage, there may be the formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans.

questions.text: A CT scan of a teenager revealed an inflamed appendix in the pelvic position. On examination, the patient experiences pain in the right lower quadrant on internal rotation of the hip. What is the sign called?
questions.solution:
Pain on flexion and internal rotation of the hip is called the obturator sign.  Spasm of obturator internus is responsible for this pain.

Acute appendicitis typically presents with abdominal pain that is initially difficult to localize. This pain arises from discomfort in the midgut due to inflammation and blockage of the appendix. It often begins in the periumbilical region that is accompanied by loss of appetite, feelings of nausea, and typically one or two instances of vomiting that occur after the pain starts. Loss of appetite is a consistent and helpful symptom, especially in children who almost always also experience vomiting.

The tenderness associated with acute appendicitis is located at a point called McBurney point, which is positioned one-third the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus.

 The Alvarado scoring system is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. In children, ultrasound is the imaging of choice while in adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient with diabetes has uncontrolled blood glucose levels despite taking metformin. Her HbA1C levels are 8.5. She wants to lose weight and is compliant with the medications. Which of the following drugs is best suited for her?
questions.solution:
The best-suited medication for this patient is liraglutide. It will cause weight loss and improve blood glucose levels in this patient.

Liraglutide is a glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that is administered subcutaneously. It increases insulin and decreases glucagon secretion, thus causing more uptake of glucose into extrahepatic tissues. Furthermore, it slows gastric emptying and improves satiety. It thus causes weight loss. Other GLP-1 analogs also have a similar mechanism of action, and include exenatide, dulaglutide, and semaglutide. Semaglutide is the only GLP-1 analog available as an oral formulation.

There have been reports of an association of pancreatitis with GLP-1 analogs. GLP-1 receptor is also expressed on thyroid C cells and these drugs have a theoretical possibility of stimulating these cells. Thus, GLP-1 analogs are best avoided in patients with medullary carcinoma of thyroid or with a predisposition to pancreatitis.

Other options:

Vildagliptin (option B) belongs to dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DPP-IV) inhibitors. They act by inhibiting the breakdown of endogenous GLP-1 and prolonging its action. While it increases insulin and decreases glucagon secretion, it does not affect gastric emptying and satiety. Thus, it does not affect the body weight. 

Glimepiride (option C) belongs to sulfonylureas. It increases insulin secretion from the β cells of the pancreas. It causes weight gain and thus is not preferred for this patient.

Subcutaneous insulin (option D) is a reserve drug in type II diabetes mellitus, used in the following scenarios:

  • HbA1C > 10 on presentation
  • Lean patients or those who have had severe weight loss due to diabetes
  • Underlying hepatic and renal diseases which prevent the use of oral antidiabetic drugs
  • Acute illness or hospitalized patient

It also causes weight gain and thus is not preferred in this patient.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents with right-sided weakness for the last 2 hours. NCCT head does not show any intracranial bleeding. His BP is 200/120 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
In a patient with ischemic stroke and who is otherwise a candidate for IV thrombolysis, the BP should be maintained <185/110 mmHg. If higher than this, then antihypertensive agents such as IV nicardipine are used to reduce the BP.

As soon as the diagnosis of stroke is made clinically, a non-contrast CT (NCCT) of the head is done to differentiate between hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke, because the management of the two is entirely different. Once an ischemic stroke is confirmed, the goal is to limit the size of the infarct by optimizing perfusion to the penumbra. Since the blood flow in the ischemic areas of the brain is dependent on high blood pressure, the target blood pressure is higher than normal in ischemic stroke. Antihypertensives should only be administered if:

  • BP is >220/120 mmHg
  • BP is >185/110 mmHg and the patient is planned for thrombolytic therapy

The antihypertensives preferred for this purpose are IV labetalol, nicardipine, and clevidipine. They allow rapid titration to the target blood pressure. After the BP is optimized, a thrombolytic agent is administered intravenously unless there are contraindications.

After this, CT angiography is done to find out if the occlusion is in the larger arteries of the brain, such as the internal carotid artery, middle cerebral artery, and basilar artery. Such occlusions involve large clots and fail to open with IV thrombolysis alone. For these patients, mechanical thrombectomy is done. Mechanical thrombectomy is also indicated in patients presenting after 6 hours but within 24 hours, with the CT showing good perfusion of the penumbra.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text:
Match the following patients with their respective speech audiometric graphs.
  1. A patient with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus.
  2. A patient with hearing loss and tinnitus and MRI showing "ice-cream-cone" appearance.
  3. A patient with right sided hearing loss and Weber's test lateralized to right ear.
  4. A patient with normal hearing.
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

  1. A patient with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus (Meniere's disease) - Graph C
  2. A patient with hearing loss and tinnitus and MRI showing "ice-cream-cone" appearance (Acoustic neuroma)- Graph D
  3. A patient with right sided hearing loss and Weber's test lateralized to right ear (Conductive deafness) - Graph B
  4. A patient with normal hearing - Graph A

In speech audiometry, the patient’s ability to hear and understand speech is measured. Speech reception threshold (SRT) and discrimination score (DS) are studied under this test.

The speech reception threshold (SRT) is the lowest intensity of sound at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient. Speech discrimination scores test the capacity of the patient to understand speech. Hence, speech audiometry is a subjective test which is difficult to perform in children of younger age.

Roll over phenomenon (Graph D) which is seen on plotting discrimination score against amplitude of sound is diagnostic of Retrochochlear pathologies that is indicative of neural hearing loss. Here, the phoneticaly balanced (PB) word score falls with increase in speech intensity above a particular level due to nerve fatigue.

The graph in cochlear disorders (Graph C) will rather show a plateau after a certain level unlike the fall seen in roll over phenomenon. 

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the orthopedic department with pain and swelling in the right thigh for a few weeks. X-ray of the right femur showed a lesion as shown below. Whihc of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It arises most commonly from the metaphysis
t(11:22) is the most common translocation
It most commonly occurs in the 2nd decade of life

questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a 6-year-old boy with painful swelling in his thigh and an X-ray showing onion skin periosteal reaction is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma. They commonly occur in the diaphysis.

Ewing sarcoma most commonly occurs in the 2nd decade of life(Option B). It is also the most common malignant tumor in the first decade. The long bones affected are the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus in that order. About 20 percent of tumors are seen in flat bones. They commonly occur in the diaphysis.

The patient presents with pain, which is intermittent in nature. The pain is worse at night. The tumor is diaphyseal and fixed to the bone, the skin is red, and dilated veins may be present. There may be a history of trauma preceding onset, but it is usually incidental.  It is associated with fever which may be confused with osteomyelitis.

Radiographic Features

  • The lesion could be lytic, sclerotic, or mixed.
  • A diaphyseal lesion with irregular destruction (moth-eaten appearance or cracked ice appearance)
  • Periosteal reaction is deposited in layers giving an onion peel appearance.

Cytogenetic examination showing t(11:22)(q24:q12)is the most common translocation diagnostic of Ewing's sarcoma(Option C). They stain positive for MIC-2(Option D). Histology shows small blue round tumor cells that are PAS-positive, as tumor cells are rich in glycogen. However, they stain negatively for reticulin.

Ewing sarcoma is radiosensitive. Large unresectable tumors are treated with radiation while small resectable tumors are more likely to be treated with surgery. Treatment always includes adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient presents stiffness in the joints of the hands for the past 6 years. On examination, the following deformity is noted. Serology is positive for anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following are associated with this condition?
  1. Pleural effusion
  2. Sjögren syndrome
  3. Membranous nephropathy
  4. Uveitis
  5. Seizures
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with stiffness in small joints of hands, the positivity of anti-CCP antibodies, and the image showing swan-neck deformity point to a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. Pleural effusion, Sjögren syndrome, and membranous nephropathy are seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

The extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis include:

  • Secondary Sjögren syndrome, often presenting as keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia
  • Ocular: episcleritis, scleritis (not uveitis, statement 4)
  • Neurological: cervical myelopathy (not seizures, statement 5)
    Cervical myelopathy occurs due to the instability of the atlantoaxial joint, and presents with UMN signs such as spasticity, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar response. The patients also complain of pain in the neck radiating toward the occiput.
  • Pulmonary: pleural effusion, interstitial lung disease, pulmonary nodules
  • Cardiac: pericarditis, myocarditis, arrhythmia
  • Renal: membranous nephropathy, amyloidosis
  • Hematological: Felty's syndrome (the triad of rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and splenomegaly), anemia of chronic disease

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Through which receptor does the virus responsible for infectious mononucleosis enter the epithelial cells of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis. EBV enters pharyngeal epithelial cells through CD 21 (or CR2) receptors. They are the same as those for the C3d component of complement.

EBV may lead to the following presentations:

  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Burkitt’s lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Lymphomas in immunodeficient persons such as AIDS or transplant recipients.

EBV multiplies inside the lymphocyte in two ways. First, they immortalize the lymphocytes that they infect leading to uncontrolled growth. The cells produce different types of immunoglobulins as a result. The second way they damage the lymphocyte is by causing lysis leading to the release of virions. 

In infectious mononucleosis, the infected B lymphocytes express EBV antigens on the cell surface. The atypical lymphocyte seen in EBV infections is due to T lymphocytes transforming in response to the infected B lymphocytes.

Other options:

Option A: CD 1 receptors are associated with thymocytes and Langerhans cells. 

Option B: CD 3 receptors are associated with the T cell antigen receptor complex.

Option C: CD 8 receptors are associated with suppressor/cytotoxic T cells.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below. Which of the following structures is not cut during the procedure most commonly carried out by this instrument?

choices.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal  nerves

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is an episiotomy scissors. The obturator muscle is not cut during mediolateral episiotomy which is the most commonly done procedure using this instrument.

A surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour is called an episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J shaped episiotomy.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
Match the given conditions with the mechanism causing edema in them.
Conditions Mechanism
1. Lymphatic blockage a. Increase in capillary pressure
2. Nephrotic syndrome b. Increase in capillary permeability
3. Heart failure c. Increase in interstitial oncotic pressure
4. Infections d. Decrease in capillary osmotic pressure
5. Liver failure
questions.solution:
The correctly matched conditions and mechanisms causing edema are: 1- c, 2- d, 3- a, 4- b, 5- d

Conditions Mechanism
1. Lymphatic blockage c. Increase in interstitial oncotic pressure
2. Nephrotic syndrome d. Decrease in capillary osmotic pressure
3. Heart failure a. Increase in capillary pressure
4. Infections b. Increase in capillary permeability
5. Liver failure d. Decrease in plasma proteins

Option 1: The lymphatic system returns small amounts of proteins and fluid that leak into the interstitium back to circulation. In case of lymphatic blockage, these proteins and fluids cannot be cleared and instead accumulate in the interstitium. This fluid accumulation leads to edema. The accumulating proteins increase the interstitial colloidal osmotic pressure and draw more fluid into the interstitium.

Options 2 and 5: In nephrotic syndrome, there is a loss of proteins in the urine while in liver cirrhosis there is failure of production of proteins. Both of these conditions result in decreased plasma proteins. Plasma proteins are responsible for the capillary colloidal osmotic pressure that causes the osmosis of fluid into the capillary. A decrease in the capillary oncotic pressure causes more fluid to move into the interstitium, causing edema. 

Option 3: In heart failure, there is an inability of the heart to pump out the blood. This pump inefficiency causes back pressure and an increase in venous and capillary pressure. This increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure forces the fluid out of the capillary and causes edema.

Option 4: Infections cause inflammation and membrane damage. This leads to increased capillary permeability and fluid leaks into the interstitium causing edema.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein values be the lowest?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, Maternal Serum Alpha-Fetoprotein is lowest in Down's syndrome.

Alpha fetoprotein is an oncofetal protein. It is produced by the yolk sac and fetal liver. The highest level of AFP in fetal serum and amniotic fluid is reached around 13 weeks and thereafter it decreases. Maternal serum level reaches a peak around 32 weeks.

MSAFP level is elevated in the following conditions:

  • Wrong gestational age,
  • Open neural tube defects (Option D)
  • Multiple pregnancy (Option C)
  • Rh isoimmunization
  • IUFD
  • Anterior abdominal wall defects (Option B)
  • Renal anomalies

Low levels are found in trisomies (Down’s syndrome), and gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: Blood is collected in a grey-colored vacutainer to measure blood glucose level. Which substance is present in this vacutainer?
questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride present in the grey-colored vacutainer inhibits glycolysis. Hence, is used for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol.

The Clinical & Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has recommended a color sequence for multiple collections of venous and/or arterial blood samples in a single patient.

Yellow, pink, and blue → light Blue → red → green → lavender → grey

Other options:

Option A: Green vacutainers contain Heparin.

Option C: Purple vacutainers contain K2 EDTA. This helps remove the calcium by forming salts and is used to collect samples for hematological studies and cross-match samples.

Option D: Light blue vacutainers are coagulation tubes and contain sodium citrate. It is used to collect samples for coagulation tests such as prothrombin time.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 2-week-old female baby was brought to the clinic with mucopurulent discharge from both eyes. On examination, the eyelids appear swollen and the conjunctiva is erythematous. PCR done on the conjunctival scrapings detected Chlamydia trachomatis.  What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette with the time of presentation of symptoms is strongly suggestive of ophthalmia neonatorum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition among the given options is oral erythromycin. 

Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis can be considered as conjunctivitis that develops within the first month of life. The causative agents are Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, Haemophilus influenzae, herpes simplex virus, streptococci, staphylococci, and chemical causes.

Chlamydia is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries and neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis is caused by serotypes D to K.

Clinically, Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion conjunctivitis manifests relatively late, usually over one week and up to three weeks after birth with a mucopurulent discharge, and swelling of the eyelids as shown below.

Diagnosis is usually established by PCR. Conjunctival scrapings may be used to perform a PCR. 

The treatment includes oral erythromycin for two weeks. Topical erythromycin to tetracycline ointment may also be used. 

Other options-

Option A: IM or IV ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of gonococcal neonatal conjunctivitis. It usually presents within the first week of life and is characterized by copious hyperpurulent discharge and severe eyelid edema. Supportive management may include saline irrigation to clear the copious discharge. 

Option B: IV acyclovir is used in the treatment of herpes simplex viral conjunctivitis which presents in one to two weeks with a watery discharge. It is characterized by eyelid and periocular vesicles. A corneal examination may reveal dendritic or geographic epithelial lesions. 

Option D: 1% topical silver nitrate was used as a prophylactic measure to prevent gonococcal neonatal conjunctivitis. However, it is an irritant and causes chemical conjunctivitis in the first few days of life. Hence, conservatively treatment with supportive measures such as artificial tears is preferred.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with nicotine addiction. She is a known case of epilepsy and is on medication. She was also recently diagnosed with panic disorder. Which of the following drugs should not be prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
Bupropion should not be prescribed to her as she is a known case of epilepsy and panic disorder. It is avoided in patients with seizure disorder as it lowers the seizure threshold. It is also avoided in patients with panic disorder and severe anxiety.

Cigarette smoking is the leading preventable cause of death worldwide. The FDA-approved drugs used in the treatment of tobacco dependence are varenicline, bupropion, and nicotine supplements. Clonidine, nortriptyline and cytisine are the second-line drugs used.

Bupropion is a first-line drug used for nicotine cessation and has the added benefit of causing weight loss. Weight gain is commonly seen after stopping nicotine use. Nicotine supplements are available in various forms - gums, lozenges, inhalers, nasal sprays, mouth sprays, and sublingual tablets. Combination therapy is always better than single therapy. Behavioural support and counselling play a major role along with drug therapy.

questions.text: Reed Sternberg cell morphology is pathognomonic of ___________
questions.solution:
Reed Sternberg cell morphology is not pathognomonic of any condition since they are seen in many conditions such as:

  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (commonly in immunoblastic type)
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Follicular lymphoma

A feature is called pathognomonic when that particular feature is so specific to or distinctly characteristic of a disease that it makes the diagnosis.

Note: The diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma depends on the identification of Reed- Sternberg cells in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells.

Reed Sternberg cell: It is a giant cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is accompanied by his wife complaining of tremors in his hands for 2 days. You notice that he walks slowly and in a shuffling fashion. questions.text: A 25-year-old female in her last pregnancy trimester presents with the following skin lesions and  Impetigo herpetiformis is suspected. Which of the following is best suited for her treatment?
questions.solution:
The given image showing erythema, edema, and coalescent pustules over the face is charectaristic of Impetigo herpetiformis which is also known as acute generalized pustular psoriasis of pregnancy. It is best managed with systemic corticosteroids.

Impetigo herpetiformis typically presents during the last trimester of pregnancy. It may persist until the delivery of the child, however, it may even persist longer. Clinical features include:

  • Characteristic erythematous patches with marginal grouped sterile pustules
  • Flexures affected, symmetrical
  • Centrifugal extension from the inguino-genital region
  • Grouping of areas of pustulation
  • Erosions and crusts may be present
  • Residual reddish-brown pigmentation as healing occurs.
  • Nail, mucosal lesions in tongue, mouth, and esophagus
  • May be associated with hypoparathyroidism and hypocalcemia

The mainstay of treatment is systemic corticosteroids. If unresponsive to corticosteroids, cyclosporine can also be started. Antibiotics like cephalosporins, are found to be effective as an additive treatment, even though the pustules are sterile. Narrowband UVB is considered another safe treatment when there is not an adequate response to steroids.

Complications like IUGR, PROM, and placental insufficiency are also seen. Death of the mother may occur due to cardiac or renal failure. Recurrence is common.

Steroids are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis as sudden withdrawal can trigger severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis.

questions.text:
Match the following methods of graphical representations with the appropriate types of data presented using them.
Graphs Type of data
1) Frequency polygons a) Nominal data
2) Histogram b) Interval scale data
3) Bar charts c) Trend of events over time
4) Line diagram d) Continous data
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Graphs Type of data
1) Frequency polygons

b) Interval scale data
2) Histogram

d) Continous data
3) Bar charts

a) Nominal data
4) Line diagram

c) Trend of events over time


Frequency polygons are formed by joining the midpoints of histogram blocks. It is used to represent ratio or interval scale data.

Histogram is a pictorial representation of frequency distribution and is formed by a series of blocks. It is used to represent a continuous group or data. The area under each block is proportional to the frequency.

Bar charts are used to depict nominal scale data. The length of the bar in the diagram is proportional to the magnitude that is represented. It can be simple, multiple, or component bar graphs.

A line diagram is used to depict the trends of events over a period of time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: When the pH of chyme entering the duodenum falls to 3.5, an inhibitory reflex on gastric emptying is initiated. Which of the following will not initiate the same reflex?
questions.solution:
The inhibitory reflex that is initiated in response to acidic chyme (pH 3.5) is the enterogastric reflex. This reflex may be initiated by the distension of the duodenum (not ileal distension).

Enterogastric inhibitory reflex refers to the slowing or stopping of gastric emptying in response to the following duodenal factors:

  • Distention of the duodenum -too much chyme in the duodenum (Option A)
  • The presence of any irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  • The acidity of the duodenal chyme
  • The osmolality of the chyme - either hypotonic or hypertonic fluids (Option B) initiates enterogastric inhibitory reflexes. Thus, the flow of non-isotonic fluids into the small intestine is regulated. This prevents rapid changes in electrolyte concentrations in the extracellular fluid during the absorption of the intestinal contents.
  • The presence of certain breakdown products in the chyme, especially those of proteins (Option C) and to a lesser extent, of fats. 

Emptying of the stomach is also controlled moderately by stomach factors like:

  • the degree of filling in the stomach
  • the excitatory effect of gastrin on stomach peristalsis

Hormones involved in feedback inhibition of gastric emptying:

  • Cholecystokinin (CCK)- most important. It is secreted from the jejunal mucosa in response to fatty substances in the chyme.
  • Secretin- Released from duodenal mucosa in response to gastric acid passing through the pylorus.
  • Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide or gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) - released from small intestinal mucose in response to fat and carbohydrates in the chyme.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding enzyme kinetics is true?
  1. The Lineweaver-Burke plot does not apply to suicide inhibitors 
  2. Competitive inhibition cannot be overcome by increasing substrate concentration
  3. IC50 is the concentration of an enzyme inhibitor that produces 50% inhibition
  4. Enzymes increase the activation energy barrier for reactions
  5. Noncompetitive inhibitors lower Vmax but do not affect km
questions.solution:
The true statements are: 

Statement 1: The Lineweaver-Burke plot does not apply to suicide inhibitors. Suicide inhibitors of enzymes are those that bind to enzymes and undergo catalysis to produce a substrate that binds to and blocks essential binding sites on the enzyme. It is called suicide inhibition because these substances undergo catalysis themselves to form compounds that can inhibit the enzyme. In this process, they are getting consumed. This plot does not apply to suicide inhibitors because this plot assumes that the enzyme concentration will not decrease during the course of the analysis.

Statement 3: IC50 is the less complex alternative to Ki as a measure of inhibitory potency. It is the concentration of inhibitor that produces 50% inhibition.

Statement 5: It is true that noncompetitive inhibitors lower Vmax but do not affect km.

Vmax- The maximum rate for a particular reaction with a specific enzyme

km- The Michaelis constant km is the substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) attainable at a particular concentration of the enzyme

Noncompetitive inhibitors bind to a site on the enzyme that is different from the substrate-binding site. This makes it possible for the substrate to bind to the enzyme even if the inhibitor is also bound to the enzyme. However, this reduces the efficiency of the enzymes. Hence vmax, or the maximum possible attainable speed will be lower with noncompetitive inhibitors. Km, however, which is the substrate concentration at which 50% of Vmax can be obtained will remain the same.

The false statements are:

Statement 2: Competitive inhibition actually can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration. Competitive inhibitors structurally resemble the substrate and so they tend to bind to the same binding site on the enzyme. The enzyme-inhibitor complexes (EIC) reduce the rates of these reactions, so increasing the substrate will reduce the number of EICs and help overcome this inhibition.

Statement 4: Enzymes characteristically lower the activation energy barrier for a reaction.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past 4 days. Stool microscopy is shown below. The eggs present in the stool float in a saturated solution of salt. What is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the egg seen on stool microscopy are suggestive of infection with Hymenolepis nana. 

The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colorless outer membrane and an inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution.

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest tapeworm. Man is the host. The patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with eggs of these organisms. The adult work resides in the small intestine.

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. They are usually asymptomatic. In heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may be present due to an allergic response. A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

Other options:

Option A- The fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are bile stained and float in a saturated solution of water. They are round or oval in shape. The egg is surrounded by a thick smooth translucent shell having a coarsely mamillated translucent coat. In the middle of the egg, there is a large unsegmented ovum. It covers the entire area of the egg, except for the poles.

Unfertilized eggs do not float in salt solution. They are long, narrow, and elliptical in shape. They have thinner shell with irregular albumin coating and small atrophied ovum.

The left image is unfertilized egg, while the right is the fertilized egg of Ascaris.

Option B- The eggs of the Ancylostoma duodenale are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane and a segmented ovum containing 4-8 blastomeres. The space between the hyaline shell and the ovum is clear. 

The image given below shows the egg of Ancylostoma sp.

Option D- Eggs of Trichuris trichiura are brown in color, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. They are barrel-shaped, with a mucus plug on either end. 

The image given below shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura

Retinoblastoma  Homer Wright rosettes and Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes

Neuroblastoma - Homer-Wright pseudorosettes consist of tumor cells that are concentrically arranged about a central space filled with neuropil (eosinophilic fibrillary material).

Nephroblastoma- The classic triphasic combination of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics describe the term belief?
questions.solution:
Belief is permanent and subjective. 

Beliefs tend to be permanent, subjective, and resistant to change. They are often inherited from parents, grandparents, and other individuals, shaping the unique belief systems within different communities. Due to their deeply rooted nature, beliefs can be challenging to alter. They possess the potential to be either beneficial, detrimental or have a neutral impact.

Opinions represent individuals' perspectives on a matter of disagreement and are influenced by the information accessible to them at a given time. Opinions, by their very nature, are temporary and subjective.

Attitudes are acquired traits unique to individuals, representing their ways of behavior. They consist of three essential elements: (a) a cognitive aspect related to knowledge and understanding, (b) an affective aspect connected to emotions and feelings, and (c) a behavioral inclination towards action. Attitude is permanent, objective, and relatively enduring.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. The virus most likely to be responsible for this belongs to:
questions.solution:
The presence of vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity and the images showing the characteristic lesions are suggestive of Hand-foot-and-mouth disease(HFMD). The presence of neck stiffness and the CSF showing normal glucose elevated lymphocytes and protein levels are also suggestive of viral meningitis. It is commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16, belonging to picornaviridae.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:

It is commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 which is a subgroup of enteroviruses. In large outbreaks, it is also caused by enterovirus71, coxsackie A viruses 5,6,7,9,10 and coxsackie B virus 2 and 5.

Clinical features:

  • Usually a mild illness
  • Vesicular lesions may be seen on the tongue, posterior pharynx, buccal mucosa, palate, lips, etc.
  • Maculopapular, vesicular or pustular lesions may be present in the hands and fingers, buttocks and groin.
  • Lesions are commonly seen in the hands than in the feet.
  • These vesicles resolve in a period of 1 week.
  • Infections with enterovirus 71 are more severe and are associated with neurological and cardiopulmonary manifestations.
  • Infections with coxsackievirus A16 can occasionally produce complications like encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, myocarditis, pericarditis, and shock.
  • Coxsackievirus A6 produces atypical HFMD which is a severe form.

Diagnosis:

  • HFMD is usually diagnosed clinically by the characteristic lesions.
  • Viral culture can be done to confirm the presence of enterovirus. Blood, CSF, urine, and mucosal swabs can be cultured.
  • RT-PCR testing to detect the viral genome is more sensitive and specific. PCR testing of CSF in children with meningitis is frequently positive even when the cultures are negative.

Treatment:

  • No specific antiviral agent is proven agent enteroviruses. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Milrinone is suggested as an effective agent for enterovirus 71 cardiopulmonary disease.
  • Immunoglobulins have been used to manage severe cases but with varying outcomes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with weight loss, sweating, and palpitations. On examination, she was found to have an enlarged thyroid gland. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated serum T4 and TSH levels. Further examination revealed bitemporal hemianopia. What is the next step of management for this patient?

choices.text: Start anti-thyroid drugs and wait for the symptoms to resolve.
Start anti-thyroid drugs and do MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
The patient presenting with features of hyperthyroidism with bitemporal hemianopia and laboratory investigations showing elevated levels of T4 and TSH point to the diagnosis of TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The next step of management in this patient is to start anti-thyroid drugs and do an urgent MRI of the brain.

TSH-producing macroadenomas are rare but tend to be large and locally invasive. They often cause goiter and hyperthyroidism due to excessive TSH production. Laboratory diagnosis shows elevated serum-free T4 levels and inappropriately normal or high TSH levels. Many patients with this condition also show increased levels α subunit of free glycoprotein hormones.

For tumors in the Sella turcica region, MRI has become the preferred imaging technique. Alternatively, high-resolution CT scans can be used as an alternative diagnostic tool.

The initial treatment approach involves surgical removal or reduction of the tumor mass, typically through a transsphenoidal procedure. Special care should be taken when preparing the patient for surgery, especially during the period before anesthesia. It is recommended to use antithyroid drugs or octreotide in combination with propranolol to restore normal thyroid function (euthyroidism). For patients with extremely severe hyperthyroidism, iopanoic acid can be effectively administered to alleviate the condition.

Complete removal is challenging due to the large size and invasive nature of these adenomas. Following surgery, around two-thirds of patients achieve normal thyroid hormone levels. To lower thyroid hormone levels, thyroid ablation or antithyroid drugs like methimazole and propylthiouracil can be used.

Somatostatin analogs are effective in normalizing TSH and α subunit overproduction, reducing tumor size in 50% of patients, and improving visual fields in 75% of patients. Most patients also regain normal thyroid function. However, since somatostatin analogs significantly suppress TSH, many patients may develop biochemical hypothyroidism and require thyroid hormone replacement therapy, which can also help control tumor growth.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD with a deformity as shown in the image below. The mother provides a history that the child was undergoing serial manipulations of the feet for a deformity that was present since birth with a local quack. What is the likely reason for this deformity?

choices.text: Failure to use retainer slippers after correction
Myositis ossificans due to massaging of the foot
Order of correction of the deformity is not followed

questions.solution:
The image shows Rocker-bottom feet which results when the order of correction of the deformity is not followed in cases of CTEV.

Order of correction of deformity for CTEV.

  • Correction of forefoot adduction  
  • Correction of heel varus 
  • Correction of hindfoot equinus

This order is followed to prevent Rocker Bottom Foot which develops if the foot is dorsiflexed through the hindfoot rather than the midfoot.

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are as follows:

  • Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Ponsetti's method is the currently used method for the conservative management of congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Previously Kite's method was followed.

  Ponsetti's method
Treatment start <2 weeks
Order of correction cavus -adduction - varus- equinus
Fulcrum  Head of the talus
POP type Above knee cast
Duration 6-8 weeks

 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators
